text:
This is a great recipe.  I doubled the amounts and baked in my Wilton long Loaf Pan.  Minor adaptations- my butter was quite soft so I creamed it into the sugar, my bananas were also very ripe and soft and I creamed them into the sugar mixture,I used brown sugar for a deeper flavor, I swapped baking powder for the soda for more lift and lightness.  I used non dairy sour cream.  Fantastic recipe that handles small changes well.  I sliced the loaf into 1 inch thick slices and froze in ziplock bags for lunches.  Held up very well.

I make this just about once a week. Love this recipe! I use a cup of bananas and I mash them. The first time I made it I forgot to get sour cream so I added white vinegar to 1/2 cup of milk and added 1/4 cup more flour to the recipe. It is very easy and comes out delicious every time!

text:
I have made this banana bread several times, it is excellent as written.  But here's what I have learned along the way...  Doesn't matter if you melt the butter or not, comes out the same, so I don't bother it saves time.  I have used sour cream and vanilla Greek yogurt, both work well.  Texture is the same, only difference is the bread is slightly less tangy when using the yogurt.  I think the tanginess is what I love that about this recipe so when I have the sour crème I use it, otherwise good to go with Greek yogurt.

text:
so, I have never ever made banana bread, or any other kind of bread for that matter.  So, some instruction regarding how much batter to put in the loaf pan would have been helpful.  I didn't have the recommended size of pan and the directions just say to "spread evenly"  so I filled my loaf pan.  It is currently running over the edge in my oven with 44 minutes left to cook(thank goodness I put it on a baking sheet).  It would just be nice to have little instructions like - fill pan 3/4 of the way - for those of us who are not bakers.  I'll add more to this review once the loaf is done baking and I can eat some of it.

Edit--- DELICIOUS!!!  I followed some tips from other reviews, added 1 tsp lemon juice, 1 & 3/4 cup flour, mashed the bananas and measured it to 1 cup before adding, used softened butter.  I also reduced the oven temp to 375 and baked for 1 hour and 15 minutes.  Turned out great!  Also, I used high altitude flour since I live in Colorado.

text:
I had been looking for some time for an easy banana bread recipe. Since I often have ripened bananas lying around, I wanted something I could throw together easily once a week or so to use up the old fruit. I think this bread taste-wise is quite good. It is also easy to make - basically everything in one bowl, not a lot of steps. The recipe calls for 2 bananas and I used 3 because that is what I had. It made the bread a tad mushier than I would like but I suspect that was my fault. I will make this again - in fact, I will probably throw the dry ingredients together and keep in a jar to make it even easier next time. Thank you Janet!

Display Name:
Denicalis

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/569881.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
50 plus times, that is how often I have made this recipe. As I avoid processed foods, I substituted all purpose flour for organic whole wheat flour and white sugar with organic evaporated cane sugar. I don't prefer vanilla, so I left that out. 
Also, as with most recipes, if you are using salted butter you may want to skip adding the salt. Even a pinch can become too salty.
I grease my pans with the paper towel/butter method. Works like a charm every time and is much healthier than cooking spray.
It is KEY to mix together wet ingredients in one bowl and the dry ones in another. Always put dry into wet when blending so you dont lose any of the butter or egg in the process. I have never "folded" things into recipes. I just break the bananas and blend them in well and blend in the sour cream.

text:
I've been making banana bread for years using the same recipe.  It always tasted good but it had shortening in it and I was looking for a recipe that didn't include it.  I found this recipe and at first, I was skeptical about using sliced bananas rather than mashed, but I went ahead and followed the recipe and the bread turned out fantastic!  It was so good, I made a second loaf that same day. I liked using the sour cream, it makes it super moist and really adds to the overall flavor.  I left out the nuts and added sparkling white sugar to the top before baking.  It gave it a nice crunch to go with the soft moist inside.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
BEST banana bread ever. I've made it a couple of times, and like most others have made my own MINOR changes: I use mashed bananas, rather than sliced, using a potato masher so there is some texture rather than a paste of banana. I use 1/4 c less sugar than the recipe calls for (a total of 1/2 less, since I double it) and use more ripe banana. Sometimes I add finely chopped milk chocolate instead of the walnuts (The Hubbs loves chocolate-chip banana bread). And, lastly, I use reduced-fat sour cream. I tend to bake this as a "banana bread cake" in a sprinform pan, since it's gobbled up so quickly. I have to say this is the most moist, flavorful and delicious banana bread I have EVER made. Thank you!

I joined this site just so I could comment on this bread. This bread is THE best I have ever had. I have always liked banana bread but I've never been able to eat it without first applying a layer of butter. No More! Sometimes i just grab a spoon and take a chunk. :)

In the past 3 days I've made 14 loaves of this stuff. My wife brought some to work and now everyone is wanting to by a loaf for $7-10. I followed the recipe exactly except I mash the bananas with a hand masher (not too much, its still fairly coarse). I make 2 loaves at a time and just double the recipe. Perfect every time. Thank you so much! I will make banana bread using this recipe for the rest of my life. Next batch I'm going to add some chocolate chips! OMG.

text:
I used light sour cream and added 1 tsp cinnamon.  I made this in my mixer (I read another review that said this would make it less dense: mine was a spongy moist cake).  I slice my ripe (but not brown inside) bananas as thin as I can, and enjoy the pieces in the bread/cake.    

I would like to make it with less sugar, as I find it too sweet.  Maybe 3/4 - 1/2 cup instead of 1 cup, and a mix of brown and white sugar.  Yogurt could easily sub for the sour cream.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
A few months ago, I started baking muffins for my extremely busy family so that we can eat breakfast every day.  This is their favorite recipe to date and I get ORDERS for it!  The only mods I've made (per the reviews) were 1)I use brown sugar usually and cut it back to about 3/4 cup.  The muffins come out browner and seem to hold up better.  2) Increase bananas to 3 and mash them for more consistency throughout the bread/muffin.  If making muffins, I can get about a dozen out of this recipe and they last for DAYS (we refrigerate after day 2 though).  Bake muffins for about 1/2 hour at 350 but check your oven after 25. Adding chocolate chips is a great idea too!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The key to this recipe is to MASH or PUREE the bananas.  It is equally important to add just a little less than 1/2 cup of sour cream, not a heaping 1/2 cup of sour cream.  If you add too much sour cream the bread will be spongy and wet.  Also added 1/2 teaspoon more of sugar and vanilla to sweeten it up a bit based on other reviewers suggestions.  I used whole wheat flour as a personal preference and with all of these modifications it turned out to be a 5 star banana bread.

This is such a great recipe. I use 4oz of Stonyfield any kind of yogurt on hand instead of the sour cream...usually, vanilla, or banana or pumpkin banana, my daughters favorite flavors. text:
I lost my banana bread that I had been using, so I found this one. I only changed a few things, but nothing that would affect the recipe as written. First of all, I mashed the bananas with a back of a fork due to my husband not liking hunks of bananas in his bread. I also used light sour cream, as that's all I buy and all I had on hand. I also just used softened butter, as that's what I always do with baking recipes.

The taste and the moistness were awesome! My only issue was that, even though I mashed the bananas, they still came out purple-looking. I think it's because I used 3 bananas that needed to be used, so perhaps there were too many bananas? Definitely will make this again. :D

text:
I very rarely change a recipe - especially when baking.  But, after reading reviews of many different recipes on this site, I did on this one.  I used cake flour; 1/2 brown sugar instead of all white; I only had 2 small bananas so I grated a granny smith apple along with the banana; and, I used mostly plain greek yogurt since I only had a couple spoonfuls of sour cream left.  It came out great - really moist and while it didn't have a really strong banana flavor it was still a very tasty banana bread.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/951295.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would have given it 5 stars, but with all the rave reviews I was expecting to have my socks knocked off.  However, it is still probably one of the best banana breads I have had.  I made a double batch as I had quite a few bananas; 3 frozen and 3 over ripe.  As others mentioned I did not slice them, but since the non-frozen ones were less "mushy" than the ones from the freezer I still ended up with some smaller chunks, which was nice.  I skipped the nuts since no one in the family cares for them.  Half the batch I made into mini muffins and the other half I made into a loaf.  I scooped out about 1/2 cup of batter and mixed some cocoa powder in it, then dropped about 1/4 tsp of the choco mix into each mini muffin and took a tooth pick and swirled it.  Turned out pretty good and a nice change.  In the loaf I added chocolate chips, because what's banana bread without chocolate chips?  My daughter told me the muffins were "AWESOME".  Very moist and lots of flavour.  I will make this one again.

text:
This was Ah-mazing! I used brown sugar instead of white because it was all I had. I mashed the bananas to a pulp and used greek vanilla yogurt instead of sour cream. Also I used baking powder instead of baking soda. This was so so so good! As it baked the whole house smelt heavenly. You're suppose to let it cool down, but i had a nibble when it came right out of the oven, I couldn't resist! I would suggest baking it a little less than an hour, since as mine came out a little browned along the edges. Still, that only made for a more crisp outer layer leading to a delicate soft and moist center. I bake in the night, so I hope it's still here in the morning for everyone else to have try!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Waka, waka ... is this bread fantastic!! This is definitely going to be my go-to recipe for banana bread from now on. I did tweak it according to one reviewer's suggestions:  used softened instead of melted butter; used 1-3/4 cups flour; added 1 tsp lemon juice; added 1 tsp baking powder; mashed bananas instead of sliced. I know this sounds like a lot of tweaking, but it's just basic stuff. I'm quite sure the recipe would be exceptional as-is (except I would definitely mash the bananas, not slice the buggers). Ooh, one note. When I baked it for the 1 hour, when I checked on it the bread seemed to be overbaked; it was quite brown and almost smelled burnt. However, once it cooled and it came time to eat it, I discovered that this is the perfect time to bake it, since it gave it a very nice crust. I know sometimes the top of banana bread can be almost mushy, but this one turned out perfect at the 1 hour baking time.

text:
I loved how simple this recipe is but I the taste of the banana bread wasn't as good as I was expecting. While the cake was moist I found it extremely sweet despite halving the sugar. The next time I make it will likely use about 60-70g of brown sugar instead (I converted to metric). There wasn't enough of a banana taste either. I would strongly recommend adding 1 more banana. I would also increase the walnuts to about 100g, as I found 60g is too little for the amount of batter.

text:
Fantastic recipe.  I used 1 cup of mashed bananas and added the lemon juice to it. I did use 1 tsp. baking powder and 1 tsp. of baking soda; and used 1 3/4 cups of flour total.  I placed all dry ingredients together and mixed well. In another pan, I melted the butter and when lukewarm; added the 2 eggs and mixed well and added the sour cream and mixed well, then added to flour mixture, (folded in).  Placed in 9x5 pan sprayed with baking Pam spray.  I did have to leave in oven for an additional 15 minutes. Last 20 minutes covered loaf pan with a tented foil to prevent darker top of loaf.  After 10 minutes, placed on wire rack to cool.  Delicious recipe. Thanks for sharing recipe.  My go to recipe from now on.

text:
I have found my go to banana bread recipe! I add about 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon, and mash the bananas. I also find that it is done about 10 minutes before the cooking time that is specified in the recipe. I don't add the nuts, because my daughter doesn't like them. I have made this twice so far, and it turns out brown, moist and delicious. The entire loaf gets eaten in a day, and my husband says that it is better than his mother's banana bread.

1348102
Display Name:
Linda
isPro:

13

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/743236.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this recipe five stars for deliciousness with some changes based on other's reviews.  I chose this recipe over the other banana bread recipes because others called for 3 cups of sugar and 4 1/2 cups of flour and I only wanted one loaf!!  So I made this recipe without adding any nuts and also added one extra banana (3 total). I mashed the bananas based on other's recommendations.  I also added a crumb topping before baking of 1/3 c packed brown sugar, 2 tablespoons flour, 1 teaspoon cinnamon and 1 tablespoon butter. It took an extra 20 minutes to bake (maybe because I added an extra banana??) and I had to tent it with foil the last 1/2 hour because the topping was getting too dark. But it was worth the wait. Very yummy. Thank you.

Thank you Janet -  whoever you are. This is the best banana bread we've ever had! Moist beyond belief but with a nice sweet crust.
One early reviewer said she creamed soft butter & sugar together, rather than the melted butter called for.  I agree - creamed butter & sugar is best.  Aside from that, only change I made was to add 1TBS Meyer's Dark Rum (made another banana bread recipe that called for rum & liked it). This will be my go-to banana bread recipe and I might not even share it with my friends - just keep it as my little secret!

text:
Made this for my hubby for Valentine's Day.  Followed the recipe to a T.   When I opened the oven door, I discovered that my silicone loaf pan collasped, and about 1/3 of the bread was on the bottom of my oven - that has never happened before. I bake with pan all the time (baked something else in it last night and it was fine). The bread looked very moist and not entirely baked.  The taste was very different to the bread we are used to.  I will stick with the recipe my family loves from my Country Living Cookbook.  Sorry, can't recommend this one.

text:
First time making banana bread and I must say it was a very simple receipe.  It was nice and dense, moist, and the top had a nice crunch...next time I'll make a crumble topping.  Few alterations: I added 1/2c plain low fat yogurt instead of sour cream, added 1/2 tsp of cinnamon, and 1/2 cup of chocolate chips, and I also mashed the bananas.  My husband already sneaked 3 pieces and loves it.

text:
i love this recipe....but i did make a couple changes.
1 i add more banana....i use about 4 or 5 medium bananas, to make sure it tastes extra bananay.  2 instead of walnuts (which i dont like) add almond slivers.  it gives it such a different taste than other banana breads and lastly dont skimp on the vanilla.  i use 1-1/2 to 2 tsp of vanilla.  i have made this bread about 5 times now, and its is amazingly moist and delicious!

text:
I am on the hunt for the best banana bread recipe ever, and this is currently at the top of my list!  I make it almost exactly per the recipe, the only differences being that I mash the bananas and I usually add a couple of extra tablespoons of butter.  My favorite is when it's fresh out of the oven and just cooled enough to eat!  The crust is AMAZING!!!  Unfortunately the crunchy crust goes away the next day, but it's still absolutely delicious!  I always get asked for the recipe, and have even received a marriage proposal because of it.  Yes, it's that good!

This was my first time making banana bread and this recipe was so easy I thought I was doing it wrong.  After reading the other reviews, I decided to do half a cup of brown sugar and half a cup of white and added the extra banana (2 mashed, 1 sliced).  I also added some chocolate chips.  I thought for sure with my additions I would mess it up, but I was wrong - it came out perfect!  Thanks so much for this recipe.

text:
This recipe is very good.  It vanishes quickly.  I make it to pack for breakfast for my toddler who needs a lot of calories to maintain his weight.  I add chocolate chunks, always mash the bananas, and use vanilla or banana yogurt instead of sour cream.  I use a beater too.  I am sure others take more time and care in the preparation but this works just fine and really is a quick bread to make that the whole family loves.  Very moist with good crust and comes out of the pan easy.

text:
Just as dense, moist, and delicious as promised.  My modifications based on reviews:
3 bananas.
Mushed them instead of slicing.
Added baking soda right before the oven so it wouldn't fall.
Fat free plain yogurt instead of sour cream.
Instead of sugar I used half splenda, half brown sugar and put in some cinnamon.  
Semi-sweet chocolate chips I had in the cabinet instead of nuts.
No salt.
Took out at 50 minutes.

i used the variations naples34102 seuggested except for the lemon juice. i also sed 1/2c white sugar with 1/2c brown sugar. gave it a deeper flavor and better texture/crust. all brown sugar would be good too. i also added cinnamon, about 1-2tsp would be good to give it a deeper flavor. mashes bananas are better becasue its easoer to mix in, 1cup of it. also sprinkle the top with sugar before baking, gives it a very sweet crispy crust. will be good seared in a frying pan as toast with butter. also chocolate chips are good in it to, about 1/2 cup. all in all this recipe was good, nothing completly outstading but it was tasty

text:
Ya know, sometimes you just want to get up early and throw together a nice banana bread with those blackening bananas on the counter without a lot of fuss. My old standby recipe required me to sift leavening together with the flour, soften the butter first (but not too soft!), and bring eggs to room temperature. This recipe is exactly what I was looking for...easy, fool-proof, perfectly moist, and totally fuss free! The flavor is divine. I mashed bananas leaving a few chunky pieces and added 1 tsp. cinnamon and a dash of cloves. Thank you, this recipe is being moved to the forefront of my quick bread recipes!

text:
Very moist, great flavor, and it was actually cooked all the way through the center. I have a terrible time with all my banana breads being doughy in the center and sinking in even though the edges and top are always starting to get too dark brown, but this one turned out perfectly and golden brown on top too. I did put an aluminum foil tent over it the last 15 minutes of baking. I used self rising flour, left out the salt and baking powder, and 3 bananas since it's what I needed to use up and they were small-med sized. I did mash them instead of slices. Left the nuts out. Excellent recipe!

text:
Yummy! I just took this out of the oven and it tastes delicious! I didn't buy any baking soda so I substituted with 2 tsp. of baking powder. Worked great because I like a denser banana bread! Also, I ran out of sugar so I only put about 3/4 cups of sugar, it was still pretty sweet! I added walnuts and some chocolate chips in my bread and it was soo nice! However, I don't think the banana flavor was quite enough for my taste (I mashed 2 large bananas or about 1 cup) and so the next time I make this, I will use 1 1/2 to 2 cups of mashed bananas. Loved it!

I only had one small ripe banana, my quick fix was, I went looking through my son's yogurt for whatever banana flavoring he had.  Banana creme pie is what I ended up using.  I used 1/2 white and 1/2 brown sugar.  And for anyone who has a love of baking knows creaming sugar and fat is better than melted fat. Over all super, super moist.

text:
I'm sad to say I wasn't particularly impressed with this recipe. I've been using the same recipe out of my Betty Crocker cookbook for years and have always really loved it but thought I'd try something new. This one seemed to have the best reviews and I thought the idea of adding sour cream was great.  The batter was yummy but once the bread was done I just didnt think it was very banana tasting and I had included even more bananas then called for. Plus, I thought it, although fully cooked was a little too gummy.  I'm going to stick with my tried and true Betty Crocker recipe as it's the best I've ever tasted however, I may try adding a little sour cream to it next time just for kicks. :)

Display Name:
di

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow ! I have never used sour cream in a banana bread before and was a little hesitant about how it would taste and I have always used oil . I made this banana bread following the receipe as is but added 1 teaspoon of baking powder . It was one of the best banana breads I have ever tasted and it is very moist not soggy and not heavy .It rose to the top of the pan and browned nicely and evenly . I did turn the oven off after 45 minutes and let sit in the oven for the remaining 15 minutes so as not to burn the top . My family loved this receipe and it is now a favorite that I will make often . The loaf only lasted a day ! Very easy and simple to make ... Thank -You for sharing your wonderful recepie !                di

text:
Excellent when served with fresh whipped cream, light and moist banana bread muffins with some fresh whipped cream on the side!  I mashed (very ripe) bananas, chopped pecans instead of walnuts, used only 3/4 cup sugar, added 1/4 cup wheat germ and 1/4 cup wheat bran, and subtracted 1/2 cup flour (due to the added wheat germ and bran).  This makes 12 muffins (bake for 25 minutes).

naturalbornhealer

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really great base recipe for banana bread. I made a few alterations, and it was amazing. I upped the flour to 2 cups and used a mixture of 1/3 ground almonds, 1/3 whole wheat flour and 1/3 all purpose flour. I also reduced the sugar to 3/4 cups, half baker's sugar, half brown sugar. I mashed the bananas, but left some chunks, and I omitted the nuts and added dark chocolate chips (that's what I had on hand), and I also added a little over 1 teaspoon of ground cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon ground ginger to it. Had to bake it for about 75 minutes, and it turned out great - it was gone in a day!

text:
My boyfriend and I were walking through the store one day, and I happened to notice banana bread in the bakery. I didn't get any, but after seeing it, I began craving some. So I decided to look up some recipes to make my own, and this is one that I chose. It's very sturdy and moist, but my boyfriend described it as being a bit bland, and I have to agree. It's good, but we couldn't taste a whole lot of banana flavor. I really recommend adding at least one additional banana, and as others have suggested, mashing them for a better texture. Overall, a great started recipe. Just build on it!

text:
This is a great recipe with minor changes. First, I used 3 large very ripe bananas. Instead of slicing them, I mashed them with a fork. I prefer mashing to slicing so that the bananas don't get that weird color and texture when you bake them. I also used 1/2 c of brown sugar and 1/2 c of white sugar, just because I love the taste of brown sugar. Other than that, this recipe is perfect for standard banana bread.

text:
My husband is constantly purchasing bananas and then doesn't finish all of them.  I've had lots of bad banana bread in my time and had all but given up the recipe search, but decided to give it one more try because I hate wasting money by throwing food in the trash.  I was initially attracted to this recipe because it makes one loaf with minimal work (there's only three in my family) I couldn't of been happier.  It's a fantastically easy recipe that doesn't require dirtying the KitchenAid mixer.  It has a delicious buttery taste and doesn't dry out easily.  I followed the recipe but made one addition.  I sprinkled a little cinnamon into the batter.  Having made this three times in as many weeks I feel confident in saying I've found banana bread recipe that will stay with me for life.  Thank you Janet for sharing.

text:
I loved this bread! I let the butter get to room temp, used 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup white sugar and whole wheat flour. I put 3 over-ripe bananas in a ziploc bag and mashed them up. I didn't have any vanilla extract, so I added 1/4 tsp banana flavoring and 1 tsp Frangelico hazelnut liqueur (because I had it on hand). I substituted vanilla yogurt for the sour cream and added white chocolate chips. Yum! Next time I will try using 1 cup of dark brown sugar, and try baking it at 325 degrees instead of 350 because the edges burned a little before the middle was completely done, but that is most likely due to my oven. =(

This is a wonderful banana bread! I was a bit worried, having never made a bread with sour cream and only 2 bananas (usually I use 2 cups). text:
BEST!  I have a great banana bread recipe I've been using for years.  This one beats it hands down.  What I like best about it is the crispness of the crust.  The only things I changed were to mash the banana (used 1 cup) rather than slice it and I used 1/4 cup of applesauce and 1/4 cup of butter (melted) to help keep down the calories and fat content.  I thought I might want to add less sugar next time I make it but after tasting it 1 cup of sugar is perfect - at least for my taste.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I sort of have 2 reviews for this bread.  The first time I baked it I stuck to the recipe only mashing my bananas instead of slicing because I don't like larger sections of mushy banana in my bread.  It came out excellent, didn't even last a few hours at our house!  I modified it to fit my sons dietary needs (he is on a gluten and casien free diet.)  I straight substitued applesauce for the butter, gluten free flour mix for all purpose flour (adding 3/4 tsp xantham gum) and used Tofutti better than sour cream substitute for the sour cream.  I had to bake it an extra 10 minutes but it turned out wonderfully!  My other two kids didn't even realize it was gfcf.  It turned out moist and tasty and not gritty as some baked goods do.  Wonderful recipe modified or not!

text:
I loved this bread! The moistness of it was really delicious. Mashing the bananas is really the way to go because you get all the banana flavor without the bruised chunks that some people are experiencing when slicing the bananas. I didn't chop my walnuts as small as I should have, but the rest of the family had no problems with it. I added a teaspoon of cinnamon to give it more of a "grandma is baking in the fall" kind of taste. It had just the right amount of sweetness. Love it, love it, love it!

text:
This recipe is fantastic!  I creamed the butter/sugar/egg/vanilla then sliced the bananas into this, followed by the sour cream.  I sliced them fairly thin, I did not want large chunks in the bread.  The result was perfect, nice small pieces of banana throughout.  Also faster to just cream all the wet together in the beginning.  I also topped it with a crumb topping.  Absolutely delicious, this is my new favorite banana bread recipe.

I made a few changes.  I used 3/4 butter softened not melted. 1/2 a cup of sugar instead of 1 cup, I do not like how over sweet so many american deserts are. 1/2 cup of the flour i used whole wheat. This is darn fine banana bread. I did mash the bananas and made sure I had a cup's worth, but I followed the recipe to the letter other than that - YUM! I will probably add about 1/4 cup more flour next time because I like a little more cake-like feel. But..the flavor is awesome as is. Tasted almost the same and same moisture, but oodles less fat and calories. Either way, this is awesome. Keeping this one!!

I have just made this recipe for the first time and am eating my finished product now!  It is yummy!!!  I halved the recipe because I only had one banana.  I also used half whole wheat flour/half all purpose, and added about 3/4 tsp cinnamon and a sprinkle of nutmeg. I mashed the banana and used the mixer for everything. It is really delicious!  I baked it in a 9 x 5 at 325 for 30 minutes and it was perfect (although a short loaf) :).  Thanks for the recipe!!!!  btw:  In the middle of the pan, the bottom of the loaf stayed in the pan when I inverted to cool it :(. So it's not pretty. Can anyone tell me how to prevent that?

text:
This is the BEST banana bread I have ever made (and I've been looking for a good recipe for years!).  This will be my recipe from now on.  I adjusted a few things to suit my family's taste.  I used 1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup unsweetend applesauce, 1/2 tsp. baking soda, 1/2 tsp. baking powder, added 1/4 cup more flour, a dash of cinnamon, and 1 cup mashed bananas.  Result was a fluffy and moist banana bread!

text:
Moist and delicious!!  Based on other reviewer's suggestions, I made the following changes:  used room temperature butter, which I hand-mixed w/the sugars.  I used 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup white sugar.  I added 3/4 teaspoon to the flour mixture, as well as a 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg.  I used mashed bananas (3) rather than chopped bananas.  I didn't have a loaf pan, so I ended up using 2 muffin tins.  Baked @ 350 degrees, for 20 mins.

text:
For me, this bread was just OK.  The banana bread that I grew up with is much denser, this bread is really fluffy.  The fluffiness made it a bit difficult to cut, even after completely cooling.  I think I'll stick to Mom's recipe.  Thanks though!
*****EDIT:  a few years later and after trying lots of other recipes I came back to this one and I now LOVE it.  I usually cut the sugar back to 3/4 cup and use light sour cream but other than that it's great.  Let it cool completely (overnight if you have time) and I think the flavor and texture really develops. *******

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fail-proof. I've made it twice within three days and it is gone in no time. I made a couple of changes. First, DEFINITELY mash the Bananas. Second, we live in Germany and have yet to find anywhere to get Vanilla Extract so I used vanilla sugar (at a 1/2 teaspoon = 3/4 Tablesoon ratio). Then I had a lack of sour cream and so I added just under 3 Tablespoons of milk to adjust the consistency to where I wanted and I also nixed the nuts (I've never been a fan of them in Banana Bread). I baked it for one hour and it turned out perfectly. It was very moist without being mushy. This would be a great recipe to add chocolate chips to!

country:
None
text:
This was good. I did make some changes. I used light margarine instead of butter (I didn't melt it first, just mixed it in straight from the refrigerator), half white sugar and half brown sugar, only 1/4 tsp of salt, fat free sour cream, raisins instead of walnuts, and added a tablespoon of vanilla, 1 tsp of cinnamon, a 1/2 tsp of nutmeg, a 1/2 cup of coconut, and an extra banana (I mashed all the bananas). It has a good flavor, and is nice and moist. Next time I'd like to try fat free vanilla yogurt instead of sour cream, though, as I think we'd like the flavor better. I also couldn't find this size of pan, and could only find an 8 by almost 5 pan. So, I did two of those, which meant I didn't have the nice loaf I would have had if I could have found the right size. Next time I'll make them into muffins so I don't have that problem. I would love to know what this tastes like using splenda and brown sugar baking splenda for a low sugar version. If I try it, I'll edit my review. Otherwise, nice recipe, and I'll use it again.

text:
This is a great recipe!! Easy to make and so moist and flavorful. I used three mashed bananas instead of two sliced. I did adjust the cooking time to fit my oven - baked for 75 minutes at 300. It came out perfectly. Here's a tip for making this really over-the-top: after pouring the batter into the loaf pan but before baking, sprinkle the top with a crumb mixture made from 1/3 cup brown sugar, 2 tbsp. flour, 1 tbsp soft butter, and a dash of cinnamon. This is going to be my staple banana bread recipe from now on!

This recipe worked out great and it was gone in a day!. According to other recommendations, I baked at 325 instead for an hour and 15 minutes and it turned out fully baked and moist. I substituted the melted butter for half melted margarine and half cinnamon apple sauce. I also added cinnamon and a dash of nutmeg and also mashed the bananas instead of slicing them. text:
I just finished baking this and I chose this recipe because of it's simplicity since this was my first attempt to bake banana bread.  After reading reviews, I chose to use 1/2 cup white sugar and 1/2 cup brown sugar and also mashed the bananas since I didn't think the kids would like a "chunky" banana bread.  At 1 hr the middle was not done.  At 1 hr and 20 minutes the bottom crust was getting burned but the inside bottom was not done.  I finally took it out, cut off the bottom, and served what was baked through and it was delicious.  I will try again and try to figure out how I can get it to come out evenly cooked.

I make this recipe all the time whenever I have ripe bananas.  My coworkers love this bread/cake.  Mine turns out more like a moist cake.  I follow the recipe with these changes: I make it in a 9*13 pan, add 1/2 cup of brown sugar, add some chocolate chips, and a splash of milk....

It is super yum and super easy.  It really does stay moist for days. Love it!

text:
This is a great recipe. I made it into muffins (batter made 15 muffins) and baked them for 24 min as others suggested. I also mashed the bananas (used 3, instead of 2) and added 1 t of cinnamon and a dash of nutmeg. The muffins are flavorful and light and fluffy--that surprised me most. When I think of banana bread, I think of dense, moist and heavy. If that's what you are looking for, this is not the recipe for you. If you want your muffins/bread delicious and fluffy, make this recipe.

text:
I just made this for breakfast today, and it is simply moist, lovely and delicious.

Everyone in the family loves it. I used 3 bananaas and coarsely mashed them. I also added finely chopped pecans, instead of walnuts. After an hour, the middle did not come out done, so I covered the top w/ foil at this point to avoid further browning on top, and put it back in for another ten minutes. Perfect!

Great with butter. Thanks for submitting.

text:
Very moist and easy to make.  I used three bananas, mashing two and slicing one into l/2 slices. I omitted the nuts, but next time will be adding them since I feel they would add to the overall flavor of the bread.  I prefer a recipe with more banana flavor, but it is still a very good recipe. It is a nice alternative for when you only have two or three ripe banana's on hand. Recipe makes 3 mini size loafs, remember to decrease baking time if opting for the smaller pans.  Best served warm.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/933710.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this is great but not for the diet.  I had 5 smaller really brown bananas so I doubled the recipe.  They had a wonderful banana flavor.  I chopped them up instead of slicing.(wasn't sure anyone would want a big chunk of overripe banana)and the bits of banana were great!  I won't mash my bananas from now on.  I thought I had sour cream but had picked up ricotta instead so I used 2 single serving containers of fat free yogurt.  I was weary that it would not turn out but it sure did!  The double batch made 1 8x5 loaf, 1 mini loaf tin, and 6 texas size muffins.  I filled the muffin cups up with heaping half cup each. Muffins baked for 30 minutes. The flavor is wonderful.  Except for the fat free yogurt, I didn't change a thing.  This is a great recipe if giving as a gift because of the wonderful butter flavor.  The consistency is light and airy and oh so moist, and nice carmel yellow in color. It is not heavy and dense but rich in flavor. Nice golden tops.  A really nice recipe.

text:
I have made this a half dozen times or more, and every single person who tries it falls in love with it!  I increase the recipe by 50% and bake it in a bundt pan.  I start checking it at 40 minutes and watch it until it is done.  I increase the nuts even more - to a full cup - and use pecans because they are sweeter.  Plus, I let my bananas get pretty dark and sugary before using them.  This is so easy to make and the flavor is terrific!

text:
By far the moistest (and tastiest) banana bread recipe I've ever had!   By personal preference, I skipped the nuts (am I the only one that doesn't like nuts in my banana bread)?  I listened to the other reviewers and added 1tsp cinnamon and 1/2tsp of nutmeg.  Then, I mashed the bananas up with a fork and they ended up nice and lumpy.  Apparently my loaf pan is packed away (woops!) so I made 6 monster muffins.  Prior to baking, I dusted the tops with cinnamon sugar.   Fantastic!!!  I'll definately make them again, and again, and again.

text:
Wonderful recipe! I have a couple of stand-by banana bread recipes that I've used for years (one uses mayo, the other, applesauce), but didn't have the main ingredients for them on hand so I thought I'd try this one, only to discover that my plain yogurt (which I use in place of sour cream for basically everything) was moldy! In place of the sour cream/yogurt, I used roughly a quarter cup of heavy whipping cream and a splash of lemon juice—turned out fantastic!! The outside has this wonderful light, slightly crispiness to it, the bread itself is so moist, tender and full of flavor! So happy to have another banana bread recipe to add to my growing collection! :)

This bread is very good and I would definitely make it again.  I tested it at 50 minutes and it wasn't done so I baked it the full 60 minutes as indicated in the recipe although I turned the heat down for the last 10 minutes because I felt it was getting too brown.  The only things I did differently - I added cinnamon (didn't measure, just sprinkled it in), mashed the bananas before adding them and only put the walnuts on top.  The walnuts were delicious however so next time I will mix them in.

text:
I googled “moist banana bread” and this recipe popped up.  I couldn’t make it as is because I was missing two ingredients: white sugar and sour cream.  I substituted half a cup of brown sugar and added a whole 6 oz container of Yoplait strawberry yogurt.  I figured the sweet yogurt would cover half a cup of sugar.  The result was moist and yummy!  I also put it in two pans which made the loaves short and baked in half the time.  Definitely would make this recipe again!

text:
Followed recipe exactly and it's good, but waaaay too sweet (especially if the bananas are super ripe/sweet).  For the second time, I changed it a little bit and it was even better!  
Replaced 1/2 cup of flour with almond flour, reduced the sugar to 3/4 cup (1/4 c  white sugar, 1/2 c coconut sugar) and added 3/4 tsp cinnamon.  I also mash the bananas rather than sliced.   Absolutely fantastic!  Moist and delicious.  It was still pretty sweet, so next time I'll reduce sugar by and additional 2 T.

text:
This is a great recipe. 
To make it healthier I use:
1/2 cup coconut oil (softened)
1 cup sugar (maybe coconut sugar)
2 eggs
1 tsp vanilla extract
3/4 cup white flour/ oat flour
3/4 cup whole wheat flour
1 tsp baking soda
1/2 tsp salt
1/2 cup plain yogurt
1/2 cup walnuts
2 bananas (mashed)
For my high altitude it is easier to bake in 9" by 13" baking dish at 350 degrees for 50 minutes.

text:
This banana bread recipe turned out delicious! I did make a couple of changes, but nothing too drastic. I used (4) mashed bananas (mine were small).  I substituted a 1/4 cup pecans and 1/4 cup almond meal for the walnuts, and used  1/2 cup brown and 1/2 cup white sugar. I added a teaspoon of cinnamon, and only used 1/4 cup of sour cream. My bake time was only 50 minutes and I let it cool in pan out of the oven for 5 minutes,  before inverting onto a wire rack to cool completely. I'm excited to try this recipe with pumpkin, sweet potato, or apples in the Fall :)

text:
As usual, some ingredients were not available.   I used Splenda instead of sugar.  Used Buck-ees Sugar Coated Cashews instead of walnuts.  I think the small amount of sugar helped the browning of the loaf overall.   These had a vanilla flavoring helping the fact that I could not find my vanilla.  It came out great, even with these changes. 

 Note that one of the problems with Splenda's browning capabilities: 
sugar caramelizes, Splenda does not.

Baked in a buttered muffin tin. Used light brown sugar instead of white, used organic bread flour instead of all purpose so I added a tsp of baking powder.I added coconut, a fat tsp of cinnamon, ½ tsp nutmeg and a 1/2 tsp of organic dehydrated ginger. I didn’t have any nuts so left them out. Even with all these changes, these were so moist and flavorful and came out easily without muffin tin papers or liners. These will go fast!

Delicious!! Like some others, I used 3 bananas, mashed up (one cup). I whisked together all the wet ingredients (including the sugar and bananas), then added the flour, salt and baking soda, and lastly stirred in the walnuts. I out them in a muffin tins and baked for 25 minutes. It made 16 muffins - I may fill them a little more next time so they fit in one muffin tins. My kids are going bonkers over these! Definitely making over and over again.

text:
These were the suggestions in the first review. *cream the softened butter with the sugar (not melted). I add 1 tsp. lemon juice with the vanilla, and use 1 tsp. each of baking soda and baking powder, and 1-3/4 c. flour. Finally, regardless of how many bananas are used it should equal 1 cup.* I followed these suggestions exactly and the rest of the recipe as written; it was superb! It was moist, just sweet enough w/o being overly sweet, and absolutely delicious. I mashed the bananas up with a wooden spoon in a 1-cup glass measuring cup until it was full. I made it one morning and it was gone by the next morning.

text:
I’m with NAPLES 34102
I followed her adjustments except I used the juice of the whole lemon.  I make everything with spelt flour rather than wheat. 
I cook outdoors in a roaster (no glass cover) so you can imagine how tricky baking anything is. This had the most marvelous flavor. I especially liked having sliced bananas so I can actually get a contrasting texture with the banana versus the bread.
 I’ve been making banana bread for years and I don’t know why but the flavor of this was absolutely divine.  I used heavy cream and THIS is the recipe I will be using from here on out.
My remote thermometer is broken so I had to keep taking the cover off the roaster. Anticipating the center not cooking properly I split it into two loaf pans instead of one. When my thermometer arrives I’ll just put this in one loaf pan as usual. Still tasteS great!!  Highly recommend *****

text:
Like many others, I made a few adjustments: creamed the butter and sugar together, and added butterscotch chips to the batter and as a topping. I used an 8x8in pan and it came out PERFECT! It took about 58 minutes. I thought it would end up dry, but after storing in an airtight container overnight, it somehow became more moist than it was shortly after baking and cooling. The sour cream really makes a difference and this is a recipe I'll use again and again!

userID:
13365463
Display Name:
KAM
isPro:
False
followersCount:

2

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a Christmas hit! Based on reviews, I made the following modifications - used softened butter, not melted and creamed butter and sugar using a hand mixer; used 1 cup mashed bananas vs 2 sliced (I bake my bananas in the skin, and walnuts in the shell, in the oven first for 25mins); added 1 tsp lemon juice to bananas; reduced sugar by 1/4 cup and used 1/2 cup brown and 1/4 cup white instead of all white; added 1 tsp baking powder along with the baking soda; doubled the vanilla; increased flour by 1/4 cup; added a sprinkle of cinnamon and nutmeg, and decreased the sour cream by half. I also changed the order and added the bananas after the eggs and beat with hand mixer, then folded flour mixture in with a spatula and then folded in sour cream (and nuts if desired). Do not overbeat. It dries out the bread. Bread was so moist and delicious! Absolutely perfect. People were still looking for more after it was all gone! I managed to save a slice, and it was even more moist 2 days later.

country:
None
text:
HEALTHY VERSION:  What a delicious banana bread. With a few substitutes I made a healthier version.  It turned out amazing!  I also doubled the recipe and froze 1 loaf.  I used low fat sour cream; half white sugar and half brown sugar/Splenda blend; 1/2 white flour and half whole grain buck wheat flour. As in other reviews I used 1 tsp. Lemon juice and 1 tsp baking powder and 1 tsp baking soda.  I mashed the bananas and cooked 40 minutes checking with a toothpick after 5 minute intervals. Total cook time was 55 minutes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'll make this again! Simple recipe. Loaf is moist inside and taste is great. Notes:
1. I sprinkled the walnuts on TOP before baking, rather than folding them in, looks nice, and kids can easily avoid them. 
2. Ran out of sour cream, used nonfat greek yogurt to fill the measuring cup up, no issue.
3. Baked in glass loaf pan on middle rack at 350 for 50 min. Next time I'd drop temp to 325, or take loaf out 5-10 min. earlier (edges are dry and bread is too dark on bottom).

userID:
11584027
Display Name:
rirybakes
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a baker, I have memorized and used this recipe so many times for many years. I volunteer a lot with my church and among my fancier desserts like tiramisu, cheesecake, and creme brulee, my banana bread is always the surprising request despite how easy it is. I have often multiplied this to feed hundreds in the snowy mountains for long workdays and am often asked to make this at retreat camps as well. I've done many variations and just know that as long as you MASH your bananas, and never forget to use EITHER sour cream or yogurt (honestly whatever you have on hand), you'll be fine. I have seen that it honestly doesn't matter if you "accidentally" throw an extra banana or use oil instead of butter, melted vs softened... none of that is going to fundamentally change this recipe - just don't omit the sour cream/yogurt. That's the game-changer. In the California mountains, I could only find those strawberry and peach flavored yogurt cups and it was still great (a lil extra sugar and fruit don't hurt). There's one man who literally yells "where's my banana bread?!" every time he sees me now since I made that in the mountains and it's become a running joke. People think I'm crazy for having memorized this but it's a simple recipe that honestly can't go wrong given how many times, for how many people, and in how many places I have made this recipe. After about 12 years of using this, I felt I should give the recipe its much-owed respect for the oddly undeserved fame it has won me.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I pretty much stuck to the recipe except for about 1/2 cup more bananas and I only had X large eggs. The last time I made it, someone indicated that they thought there were too many bananas in the recipe, but I thought it needed more and it did turn out more delicious with the added bananas. I accidentally baked it on 375 degrees so it was done after 45 minutes. It's wonderfully moist on the inside and just the right amount of sweetness. I would like to add nuts but my kids hate them. It's still good without them.

This banana bread is as good as my Grandma Minnie's (the best cook ever!) I think she put buttermilk in hers. I sent some to my sister's house (2 of her grandchildren and my Mother live there). The next day she brought me 4 over ripe bananas and requested a double batch! They all loved it so much! I made a double batch of this recipe yesterday. After an hour,  the top of both loaves were well browned but they didn't pass the toothpick test. I had to bake them for another 25 minutes. They turned out just right. I don't know what the difference was this time, but I'm glad that I checked them.

None
text:
Best recipe I have found for Banana Bread. I read many comments and didn't melt the butter, used half white and brown sugar, had eggs at room temp and whipped them a little, used half whole wheat and half white flour, used 1 t. lemon juice, made it with 1 t. baking soda -adding it LAST - and 1 t. baking powder, used less than 1/2 c. sour cream - 1/4 or so, used mashed bananas - from freezer - thawed, added 1/2 t. cinnamon, 1/4 t. cloves, will add 1/4 t. nutmeg next time - was out.  Will used pecans next time, as I didn't want to use nuts until I found out if this worked. I LOVE THIS RECIPE - the rest of my recipes will be trashed! Thank you to all the people for all the suggestions. I used almost all of the ones I read!!! Love it! Put cinnamon and sugar on the bottom of the pan after I spayed. Put cinnamon and sugar on top of the loaf before baking.

text:
I must have made this bread at least 15 times in three years, I make sure to use carry gold butter the richer the butter the more tender the inside and I always add some kind of shaved chocolate something salted is really nice along with either pecans or walnuts. Also I undercook by 10 mins, because I like a pudding texture.  We’ve got renamed it the promise bread because people are always asking me to promise to make it. I don’t know who Janet is, but this is by far my favorite recipe I have found online that I keep re visiting.

text:
I switched out the bananas for frozen blueberries, lemon zest and lemon juice. I four times the recipe and it made 7 mini loafs. I used the zest and juice from 6 small lemons. I placed a sheet of foil over the top of them at the 30 minute point, and bake them for another 30 minutes. The crust was hard but oh so good! Next time I make it, I will be cutting the sugar in half as it was too sweet for me, even though my friends didn't complain about the sweetness. I will also be reducing the amount of lemon juice I will add the next time around as well.

Display Name:
ilvsnow524

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everytime I make this I get compliments.  Great recipe.  I have changed a few things .  I add 1/2 cup white sugar and and 1/2 cup brown sugar instead of 1 cup white sugar.  I melt butter first and use a basting brush to coat bread pan with some of the butter.  Then I take the white sugar pour it in the bread pan and coat the sides and then pour the sugar that doesn't stick to the pan in the bowl to mix with the rest of the ingredients.  That makes a nice sugary coating on the sides of the bread without adding more sugar.  Depending on the softness of the bananas sometimes I slice them and sometimes I just mush them in.  Last I reserve a little of the brown sugar and sprinkle that on top with a little cinnamon before baking.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve made this recipe a few times now and I’ve finally perfected it to my liking. I did add 1/2tsp. Baking powder. I used three very ripe bananas instead of two. I brushed the top with butter when it came out of the oven and I also placed this in a glass covered cake dish once it was done to trap the steam and make all those outer crusts super moist like the bread itself. I’m not a fan of crispier crusts. I also added 1/4tsp. Of cinnamon to the batter. This recipe is very flexible and good as written but I feel these changes make for the banana bread my grandma used to make.

text:
This is a wonderful banana bread. I did change the method of mixing, as others have mentioned. I mashed the bananas,  creamed soft butter and the sugar together, then added the vanilla and eggs. Then flour mixture, followed by the rest of the ingredients. Also, toast those nuts! It only takes a couple of extra minutes, and it makes so, so much better. Great depth of flavor.

Excellent Recipe and Delicious

I substituted pecans for the walnuts an used 4 very ripe small bananas. No need to mash bananas beforehand, just add them into the mixture as described....I had no lumps or clumps of bananas in the bread.  The spices, instant vanilla pudding an the butter crisco is what makes this recipe so deliciously  ‘moist’.  I definitely will make this again!

text:
If I could give 6 stars, I would. This is hands down the best banana bread recipe I’ve EVER made. Most banana bread recipes end up being dry and overcooked, or completely underdone. I followed this recipe almost as is, just used an extra 1/4 cup of sour cream (I put a good amount of sour cream in almost everything I bake to ensure it gets cooked all the way, but stays moist), replaced walnuts with chocolate chips, and of course I mashed the bananas rather than sliced them. This is a recipe I will be using for the rest of my life! Thank you!

city:

country:
None
text:
This is SUCH a good banana bread.  Made it as per recipe the first time and it was great.  Experimented the second time with this:  used Vietnamese cinnamon. It has a much higher cinnamon oil content and makes a world of difference.  If you can't find it you can order it from King Arthur's flour.  Next, I used more banana, and finally, I grated FRESH nutmeg and made it into over the top banana bread.  I had to go to a "health" food store to find a nutmeg.  If you go to a regular grocery store they are SO expensive but if you go to the health food store you can buy ONE.  I think mine cost 50 cents.

text:
This is a great basic BNB recipe. And I say that because it was pretty good, but wasn't great... And I followed the recipe almost to a T, except that I thought 2 bananas was too few, so I added half a banana more.

So, yes, very moist, and light, crisp crust when fresh out of the oven. But, I probably should have read the reviews before making it, as more bakers said that they added more bananas, and also a lot of them added more spices. And, when I tasted it, it definitely could have benefitted from those additions. I needed more banana flavor. And, I also believe the mashing vs slicing could have helped the flavor distribute better. Next time!

text:
Rarely write reviews but this recipe deserves my two cents.  In my 68 yrs I have made hundreds of loaves of banana bread from many recipes (and eaten many made by others) but I will never use another recipe.  Made this yesterday and am ashamed to say how many slices I have eaten but this is the best banana bread I have ever eaten. It is so moist, makes a large loaf and flavor is intense and so flavorful. Followed recipe to the letter with one exception...had 3 ripe bananas on hand so used all 3. Don't know if that made a difference, doubt it, but will stick with 3 in the future as it was perfect for me.  This bread is perfection and can't wait to make for family and friends.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To me, this is classic banana bread that you would find in a bakery: it's on the sweeter side and it's high enough in fat that it leaves a little grease on your fingers after you've had a slice. What I love the most is the crust: it has a crunch to it but is also almost fudgey due to the sugar content. I did use 3 bananas because I had 3 I needed to use up, and I mashed them of course. I love this recipe because it's perfect if I am having a sweet tooth week, and I can cut back down on the sugar and fat when I am craving a healthier bread. And I always add 1 cup chocolate chips. Other than that, I do melt the butter as stated. I feel banana bread should be quick to make and I can't be bothered with any creaming. I plop the batter into parchment paper I press down into a mold which is always a little scrunched up in the corners. Wet and dry ingredients are mixed in the same bowl.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! Very moist and nice that it has minimal ingredients. The only reason I didn’t go five stars is because they call for fresh sliced bananas. I could only imagine what that texture would be like, and the next day having black mushy bananas in your bread is not good. So I subbed and used old bananas that I keep in the freezer when they start going bad sitting around on the counter. Just thawed 3 of those and then mashed up before adding to batter as recipe called for at end (which is the only way I make banana bread, never use fresh). Good recipe, will use again for sure.

country:
None
text:
I made this in my Breadman Plus on the “Batter” cycle. This was my 1st time using that  cycle. I made a few changes as recommended by others:1 3/4 c flour, 1 tsp each of baking soda and baking powder. I mashed 2 large bananas which equaled 1.25 cups. I substituted 1/4 c of honey for 1/4 c sugar. I also added 3 tbsp of chia seeds hydrated very briefly in 1/2 c water. (Trying to be healthy!) Outcome was super moist and VERY tasty! This recipe is in my forever favorite recipes!

text:
Soooo good!  This recipe is very easy to make and comes out super moist and delicious.  The only things I changed were, first, I substituted the flour for a gluten free flour blend (Namaste brand Organic Perfect Flour Blend) and, second, I used a plain Greek yogurt with a Tbsp of fresh lemon juice as a replacement for sour cream.  I also had to cook it an additional 5 minutes and it still came out insanely moist!   I should've cooked it another 5 additional minutes.  Overall, this recipe is easy, yummy, and most.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So moist! I made some minor modifications based on what I had in my kitchen, but feel overall I followed the recipe. Will definitely be my go-to banana bread recipe from now on. I mashed the bananas because that's what I'm used to with banana bread. I also used 3 bananas because that's how many overly ripe ones I had. I used 1/3 cup of plain greek yogurt instead of sour cream. (I decreased the greek yogurt measurement slightly because of the extra moisture from bananas - I have no idea if that was actually necessary.)  I also added 1/4 tsp cloves, 1 tsp cinnamon, and 1/4 tsp nutmeg. I wouldn't recommend the cloves though. I'd like more banana flavor and less spice, my bad. I'll make again without adding spices to see how it goes.

Display Name:
smessina10

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6849213.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With a few variations, this is now my favorite recipe for banana bread. First thing, I used room temperature butter and creamed it with the sugar. Like others have mentioned, I mashed the bananas, and I used 3 very ripe bananas. I didn’t have walnuts on hand so instead I put in my food processor about 1/4 cup whole almonds, 1/8 cup old fashioned rolled oats, and 2 tbsp brown sugar. Pulsed that to crumb consistency and this was the topping of my banana bread. I covered the entire top of the batter with it so none was showing through. Baked mine for about 1 hour and 10 minutes. I think this is now the perfect recipe for banana bread and I’ll never use a different one!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe several times with my 12 y.o. daughter.  It's very easy and flavorful.  I saw another reviewer say that she used cream cheese instead of sour cream.  We did that one time as well.  There was no perceivable difference in flavor. 

We skipped the nuts but added choc chips in one loaf.   If you do that, choose the mini morsels.  Otherwise they sink to the bottom of the batter while it is cooking.  Also, milk choc tasted better than dark choc.  

Love the versatility with this recipe!

text:
Because I didn't have enough walnuts I used some chopped pecans as well, and some dark chocolate chunks. I diced my bananas rather than sliced them and made sure to use full fat sour cream. Might be too runny if I used a lower fat version. I had to leave it in my oven for 70 minutes but then it was perfect. I'm very happy with the results.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe. I have made it as is and it's very good. This time I made a few changes because I didn't have sour cream and to adjust to my liking. I used 1.75c of flour, 1tsp baking soda, 1tsp baking powder, 1TB cinnamon and 1/2c Greek vanilla yogurt.  I added the baking soda, baking powder, and cinnamon to the flour and used the yogurt in place of sour cream. I also added a pinch of vanilla bean paste to the vanilla and 1tsp of lemon juice. Baked at 325 for 1.15 hours. I think I'm sticking with these changes! My SO ate an entire loaf right out of the oven!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this tonight, and it is the best banana bread I’ve ever had. I followed the recipe with a few exceptions, based on some other reviews. I added 1 tsp lemon juice with the vanilla. I used 1 3/4 cups flour, and used 1 tsp each of baking powder and baking soda. Instead of sour cream, I used 1/2 cup of honey flavored Greek yogurt. I also used 1 cup of mashed banana. The bread turned out dense and moist on the inside and had a wonderful crunchy crust on the outside. Love it!!

This recipe is amazing! This is a simple and easy dessert to make. My family loves it! Very fluffy, light, and rich. Like the other reviews mentioned, I mashed the bananas instead of slicing them and it turned out great. As well I added 3 bananas instead of 2. It gave it more banana flavour. I used gluten-free flour that measures 'cup for cup', so it was a simple substitution. And I also let my 3 year old grandson help with sifting dry ingredients, peeling 3 bananas and prepping the baking dish. He was excited and in trying to keep everything on track with his help, I completely forgot to add the sour cream! I deliberately left out the nuts because of family preference. Between yesterday  evening and breakfast this morning, my  family devoured it! All declared it was the best banana bread ever. I plan to make it again with sour cream and next time get a photo before it's sliced.

text:
I Loved this recipe! It will be the only one I use from now on. I followed the recipe as it’s written but used pecans & opted to make jumbo muffins instead of a loaf. They turned out great! I did spray the muffin liners with cooking spray & then sprinkled cinnamon & sugar in them before filling them about 2/3 full. Baked them at 350 they were done in about 23 minutes. Made 11.  Thanks to whoever suggested to sprinkle the pan with cinnamon & sugar It’s a great tip!

text:
I made this banana bread recipe with a few tweaks and additions. This is a great recipe just the way it is but I love to put my own spin on things! For my first loaf I added a pint of blueberries. I tossed the blueberries lightly in flour before folding them into the mix. Turned out amazingly with the pop of blueberry. For the second loaf I added a half cup of unsweetened coconut flakes and it added a wonderful texture and light coconut taste. I had an extra overripe banana to use up so I added that to my second loaf as well.

text:
I made the banana bread as is and it came out a little dry for my liking, it probably should have been cooked for 10 minutes less. My 2nd attempt I doctored it up a bit and it was a total slam dunk! First of all I substituted half of the white sugar for brown sugar, then I mashed the bananas instead of slicing them, and added the bananas and sour cream to the wet mixture instead of after adding the dry ingredients. Then I added some chocolate chips and boom, best moist banana bread I've ever had!

userID:
3137256
Display Name:
purelex
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
21
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6788656.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time today and it was fabulous.  I did have to make a few modifications for what I had on hand (plain greek yogurt instead of sour cream and chocolate chips in place of nuts) and I also took some of the other reviewers' advice and creamed the butter and sugar (used half white, half brown sugar), added 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp nutmeg, and mashed the bananas (I used 3 medium sized).  I also coated the pan with cinnamon and sugar before I put the batter in.  Popped it in the oven in a glass dish for an hour at 350 per the directions and it is AHHHHmazing.  I might have to make more with the bananas I have frozen in my freezer because I don't think this loaf is going to last the day!

dateLastModified:

This easy recipe produces a delicious loaf of banana bread. I did use 3 very ripe mashed bananas; and left everything else as written. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe a lot of times. It is good as written with the addition of mashing the bananas.  We put ours in a big ziploc bag and the kids squish them, then I can easily squeeze it  out like toothpaste.  

Due to different times of being out of this or that ingredient, here are the changes we like the best.  Substituting half the regular sugar for brown sugar and using chocolate chips(mini work best) or a mix of chocolate and peanut butter chips instead of the nuts.   

We've also replaced the sour cream with banana flavored yogurt sometimes or even an egg with some mayo if we were short eggs. Everything has worked out well. It all depends on what we have in our cupboard.

text:
I had MANY MANY bad bananas, so I ended up tripling this recipe. I used the suggestion that someone else provided (the 1 tsp of lemon juice per  tbsp of vanilla) and I added a healthy splash of cinnamon into the batter (I also didn't slice the bananas, I mashed them, and it turned more battery in consistency)
I also greased the pans with a cinnamon/sugar/butter mix which gave them a neat crunch and folded in some chocolate chips.

MAG'S MOM

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/107579.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this as written and it was a solid 5+ stars, but I read many reviews and decided with a little tweaking it could be 10 stars.  
The changes I made were to mash the bananas to make 1 cup, and I used 1/2 white and 1/2 light brown sugar.  I added 1tsp lemon juice and also added 1tsp of baking powder and upped the flour to 1  3/4c.   I love the walnuts in it but my Mom has a hard time chewing them so sometimes when I make it I grind the nuts up fine.  That way you get the walnut flavor without the chunks.  I prefer it with chunks but it tastes great either way.  Whichever way you decide to make it, this is THE best banana bread you will ever make.  I cook more than I bake but this is one recipe I make consistently.

text:
Yummy! 4 stars because I think slicing the bananas is wrong. I only had 2 overripe bananas, and it was still good (would have been even better with a couple more). I added 1 tsp of lemon juice (per another review), 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp nutmeg, about a 1/4 cup of sour cream, a little more flour, and also did 1/2 white and 1/2 brown sugars. Did not melt butter (just creamed with sugar) and mashed those bananas! Great base recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I doubled the recipe to fit in a bundt pan. Substituted a 1/2 c brown sugar for just a half a cup of the 2 c regular sugar (1/2 c brown + 1 1/2 Sugar) , 2 teaspoons of baking power instead of baking soda, 1 stick of butter & 1/2 c Vegetable oil for the shortening. Mixed by hand until combined not to overdo like electric beaters can. Baked for about an hour at 350. Let cool 15-20 minutes. Omitted the nuts and added a cream cheese glaze to the finished bundt! Came out fantastic!

text:
I have made this recipe several times.  I have never used sliced bananas.  I would never dream of not mashing.  I love the sour cream.  I probably never make it exactly the same way.  I do use cinnamon and sugar in the bread  and on top.  Too much on the sides and bottom make it too sticky.  My family enjoys chocolate chips so add them to half of the loaves I make.  I think butter almost melted but not completely works best.

Well, I can see why its a 5 star recipe after over 5,000 reviews!  After seeing it in the latest Allrecipes magazine, I was anxious to try it...and...guess what?!?  I just happened to have exactly 3 ripe bananas!  It turned out delicious!!!!  I couldn't restrain myself, as soon as the 10 minute cooling period was up I just had to cut off a slice. country:

text:
I love this recipe.  I had made two loaves so far and making a third one all within a week time.  I made one for us, one for my sister-in-law whom craved how wonderful it was! She and her family loved it!; and I am making another one for a friend of ours.  This recipe is very easy to follow and easy to make.  I just watch the video and follow the instructions.  I use a Copper Chef loaf pan ( in which I do not have to spray or flour) and I have to bake it an extra 10 minutes. The house smells wonderful when baking.  The bread comes out excellent. I let it cool in the pan for 10 minutes and then take it out and cool it on a cooling rack for another 30-45 minutes.  My wife and I absolutely love it and we have a slice (or two) in the morning along with our freshly ground whole bean Don Francisco's French Roast/Dark Roast coffee.  It is just mmm, mmm good. 
Thank you so much for sharing this recipe on here. I give it a five out of five.

vivone

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Stellar, but need to follow recommendations of other reviewers to make it so.
1. Creamed softened butter and sugar (used only 125g sugar, compared to 200g in recipe as did not want overly sweet) with hand mixer for 1-2 minutes 
2. Beat wet ingredients (sugar, butter, eggs, vanilla) 1 minutes with whisk (could use mixer for 15-30 seconds) 
3. Added 1 tsp (5g) baking powder
4. Folded in chopped semi-sweet chocolate, approx. 1/4 cup
5. Pureed bananas for 1 cup total 

Cupcakes came out light but rich. Cake a bit dense, because I cooked for only 50 minutes. Definitely needs full 60 minutes. I used dark pans.

This got a low rating only because of my personal preference.  It is very moist.  It is very flavorful.  It is very easy to make.  The problem that I have with it is that it's more like banana cake than it is banana bread.  I like my banana bread to be a little denser.  If you like light and fluffy bread, then this is definitely the recipe for you.

text:
This recipe did not work for me.  I followed the recipe.  I see the video makes a change from the printed recipe.  The printed recipe calls for "sliced" bananas but the video mashes them.  It probably would improve the recipe if they were mashed.  In my case,  the loaf would not come out of the pan and the sliced bananas gave it a slimy kind of texture and it did not age well.  I may try it again mashing the bananas as I love sour cream coffee cake but will not slice the bananas and will also flour the pan.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this recipe tonight. 3 bananas wouldn't be bad, if you - like me, would like more banana flavor. If you add an extra banana, I guess you might need less sour cream and oil.

Can anyone recommend a way to keep the edges of the bread from browning too fast? Mine got a little burnt - more than I would have liked - and yet, the center remained really raw. (Baked for a few more minutes and it was cooked through!)

Like others said, I recommend mashing the bananas as opposed to sliced. The more overripe they are, the easier they will blend in with your other wet ingredients. 

:)

userID:
3777786
Display Name:
Fat Bear

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/227199.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After awhile, you can read recipes and know how they'll turn out. So, I did agree with naples34102 and creamed the butter/sugar, and used 1 tsp of both baking soda and baking powder. I tried her suggestion of 1-3/4 c. of flour, but it was just a little too dry. Next time, I'm going to use 1-1/2 c. of flour as is in the original recipe. I omitted the lemon juice without any negative effect.

I also liked TraceAddict's suggestion of adding 1/4 tsp cinnamon and 1/8 tsp of ground cloves. I didn't add chocolate chips as she also suggested as I've tried this in the past and it has never worked for me. Chocolate is wonderful, but shouldn't be used as a fix up: it diminishes both the chocolate and the primary recipe.

I happen to like pecans, so I used these instead of walnuts.

The sides were a bit too dry, so I'll next time use my favorite fix-up for this: take not-overripe banana slices lightly dredged in turbinado sugar and line the edges. It adds a tremendous up-kick to banana bread. Delicious.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-02-16T22:14:18.467
helpfulCount:
0

text:
I am typically not a fan of banana bread; ocassionally I'll have some that is very good. My boyfriend, however, loves it. I tried this recipe intending that he would eat most of it and then I actually ate more than he did! The only change I made was adding cinnamon into the batter and on top before baking it. The recipe did make for a pretty sweet bread but it was not overwhelming. I may adjust the sugar measurements in the future just to see how it tastes with less sweetener. But I will definitely be making this recipe again for us and for family

text:
I made this yesterday and it is very moist and very good.  I would have liked it a little sweeter so I'd probably add another 1/4 cup sugar and even a bit of cinnamon.  I've made many banana breads through the years and this one is delicious.

Today,2/8/19, is my 3rd time baking this.  The only changes I make for absolute perfection 1 3/4 cup flour, 1 1/4 cup sugar, 1/4 cup sour cream & 1/4 cup greek yogurt. Third time is the charm. Oh, and I mashed the bananas.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful, light banana bread recipe! Used room temperature eggs and butter, and took advice of others with squeeze of lemon juice, 1 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1 3/4 c flour, 1 c mashed bananas.  Makes 2 loafs, pans prepped w/salted butter and cinnamon sugar dusting. Subbed nuts w/ chocolate chips (dusted w flour so they don't sink). Have pans ready and put in oven right away, to keep batter light and fluffy!

userID:
24958646
Display Name:
aspen_strings
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
17
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used softened butter as opposed to melted butter and used 1 cup of mashed banana's in this recipe.  The banana's I used were from the freezer, so I let them thaw and tore the ends off and squeezed the contents into a measuring container.  I then used a wafflehead masher to hold the softened banana's in the bottom of the measuring cup and turned it upside down to drain out the excess water from the softening banana's.  Cooked for 65min and turned out perfect! Best banana bread I ever ate.
Review:
Rating:

country:

text:
SO good. The sour cream makes it incredible. Like the other reviewers, i mashed the banana. I used room temperature butter (not melted) and eggs. I didnt have walnuts and i think they're gross anyway so i didnt use them. Halved the sugar and used raw instead of white. I also added a bunch of cinnamon, a bit of nutmeg, and a dash of cloves, because whats the point in conquering the world for the spice trade if we're not even going to season our food. 1hr cooking was too short, i pulled it out at 1hr10 and it was slightly underdone but ended up fine after resting. I eyeballed the ingredients and it still turned out perfect. Would be good with choc chips or raspberries/blueberries too.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed this person's review and it was perfect : "With minor variations this is the recipe I've been making for 40 years. It originally came from a home ec teacher and it is beyond awesome. The differences are, first, that I cream the softened butter with the sugar (not melted). I add 1 tsp. lemon juice with the vanilla, and use 1 tsp. each of baking soda and baking powder, and 1-3/4 c. flour. Finally, regardless of how many bananas are used it should equal 1 cup. You will never find a better banana bread, and over the course of 40 years, I've never heard differently. Edited 8/17/09: My original 4/14/08 review should have indicated that I mash the bananas, not slice them."

region:

country:
None
text:
We've been making this recipe for years and have gotten many compliments.  This recipe literally takes 7 minutes to prepare (I've timed it).  My wife mixes the dry ingredients and I do the wet.  I always thought Janet made a mistake about slicing the bananas, so we've always mashed them.  By the way, if we have medium size bananas, we always throw in three.  We divide the mixture into two medium sized bread pans and bake for 45 minutes at 350.  Turns out perfectly every time.  Fast, easy, and delicious.  Try it!  Better yet, send me your address and I'll send you some.  We keep several in the freezer to give away or for unexpected guests. ??  Every now and again add chocolate chips.  I still like it just the way it is.  Thanks Janet for the quick easy recipe.  We always give you credit, and have referred folks to this page many times.
