region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazingly moist and the best banana bread I've ever made or eaten. The family loves it and we always have a loaf around now. I make double batches each time, resulting in two loafs and a dozen muffins, which if i'm lucky, they might last the week! We have passed this recipe on to several family members to enjoy as well. Wouldn't change a thing. We do use finely ground pecans, as we always have a few frozen bags of pecans around for a healthy snack. Our teenager doesn't like the larger chunks of nuts, but loves the finely ground pecans.  A perfect way to use up those brown bananas that no one will eat.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
While this is very moist, I found it to have less banana flavor than I expected. Next time I make it I will use more bananas. I altered the recipe to add another 1/2 tsp vanilla, 1/3 c mini chocolate chips and 1/3 c finely chopped macadamia nuts.  It took much longer to cook than the listed time, about 15 min. It was a hit at my house! I serve it with a spread that is 1/2 tsp of cinnamon, 1/2 c softened butter, 1 pkg of cream cheese and 1/4 c honey (cream the cheese and then add butter to prevent it from being chunky).

text:
I get requests all the time for this bread. The recipe is wonderful but I do add a few things. I love the taste of golden raisins and dried cherries so I put a handful in along with the walnuts.  This bread stands alone but the addition of dried fruits makes it so yummy and moist if those are flavors you like. It's" fruitcake like" and I give it out for Christmas.

This is the best, easiest recipe for banana bread I’ve ever made. Even my teenage son, who hates bananas, ate half the loaf! I usually don’t make substitutions in recipes, but I never have sour cream in the fridge so I used vanilla yogurt instead. I also really like cinnamon so I added that to the flour mixture. text:
I love this recipe.  I made a few minor substitutions.  I ended up using brown sugar, because I realized at the last minute, I was out of white sugar.  Still came out great.  Also I used pecans because I don't like walnuts, and I did mash the bananas instead of slicing them.  I just prefer the texture that a mashed banana gives.   My husband also gives this recipe a thumbs up!!!

I waited a week before reviewing to make sure my husband liked it.  He did.  I made it exactly as the recipe called and it was fantastic! I did add some chopped nuts and I mashed my bananas, but that was it.  Fabulous as it is.  My second making, I'm using light brown sugar...just to see.  But if you want a great and easy Banana Bread recipe...this is it!!!
UPDATE: Still making it and still one of the easiest things to bake! I don't fold anything in, I just put it in and let the mixer mix it.  Love love love this recipe!!!! (with brown sugar or regular)
**Can be made with 1:1 gluten free flour
**One batch makes 3-4 mini loaves (I made 40!!)
**moistest banana bread recipe -I've tried others since but this one is the BEST!! Don't change a thing!!

text:
I’d also agree with those who suggested mashed or puréed banana. I’d also suggest using an exact measure in the recipe, as opposed to “two medium bananas.” (The actual volume of two medium bananas on average is one cup if diced.) The real problem is that “medium” is subjective - and what makes a medium banana in some places might not be the same size banana as in other places.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Such a great recipe and so versatile! After I made the first two loaves (gone in under 24-hours), I immediately went on a banana bread kick. I made three loaves the next day (one gone in less than an hour), six regular-sized loaves and 24 mini loaves the next week, and seven more loaves the day after that! 
The co-workers LOVED it, and comments from gifted loaves included 
" Deeeeeeeeeelicious!!!!!!!! ??" 
and 
"Very good banananananna bread!"

I found that I could add more vanilla (about 1/2 tsp more), cinnamon, semi-sweet chocolate chips, peanut butter, more banana, more sour cream, less sugar, more nuts... etc. and loaves still came out AMAZING!  Have fun with this recipe! Oh, and cream that butter and sugar well. I melted half and kept half at room temp. Seemed to work well.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome and will be even better next time. I read reviews and made the following adjustments: full cup (plus a bit over) of mashed banana that was super ripe.  You can actually roast bananas in the skin to concentrate flavors even more.  I did 1 tsp. of both baking powder and baking soda. The most important thing I did, and that was after I made the first bread... I cut the sugar in half!  It was much much better with half the sugar. Honestly, why do recipes in the U.S. call for so much sugar that you can't taste the other flavors?!?! 

The first time I also added nuts and chocolate chips. My feeling is the chocolate chips overwhelm the recipe.  In addition to added even more sweetness you can't really taste the banana.  So I'm going to be a purist and make it plain!

userID:
5187637
Display Name:
Sidonia Breed Durham
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1401051.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So, as a lot of other folks stated in their reviews, I mashed my bananas instead of slicing because that's how you incorporate fruit into the bread. Anytime I use a new recipe I never alter it except for maybe the cooking time because I want to try  what the author has put out there. It's just how I do it; however, if I deem it necessary, the next time I make a recipe I will make adjustments. So this is the first time I've made this bread, and it  just came out of the oven. I followed the recipe exactly as the author intended except for mashing the bananas. The only issue I have with this recipe is in my oven (natural gas oven) I had to increase the cooking time by about 20 minutes as it was seriously gooey. I initially bake the bread for the full hour as the author indicated at 350 degrees. The bread was browning very quickly and rising as it should, as such I didn't want the bottom to burn, so I reduce the temperature to 325 degrees and cooked it for a long time additional 20 minutes. As far as I can tell, it did not burn, it looks beautiful, my house smells amazing and the bread appears to be a work of art. Now I haven't tasted yet since it's cooling,  but when I am preparing anything I'm constantly tasting and the batter itself was wonderful prior to going into the oven, so I'm sure it will be fantastic once sliced. I hope my review helps anyone that is having issues with cook times. Thanks to the author for great recipe, I'm sure my family will enjoy this!

The only changes I made were using 1/2 tsp baking soda & 1/2 tsp baking powder. I used 3 bananas, mashed. I also prepared the pan by buttering and then sprinkling all interior surfaces with cinnamon sugar. After baking, I also sprinkled cinnamon sugar on top while still hot from the oven. Absolutely delicious, moist & even the ends taste scrumptious!

text:
Outstanding recipe! Nothing but compliments on how moist and rich this bread is!

I used 3 well-ripened bananas, added a 1 tsp each of baking soda and baking powder, a dash of nutmeg and cinnamon to the flour mixture, and used butter to grease the loaf pan rather than cooking spray. I also baked at 325F for 60 minutes, and it came out perfectly moist but cooked through.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe with the following exceptions— used half butter, half oil because I didn’t have enough butter, three mashed bananas for extra banana-ey flavor, lite sour cream because it’s what I had, no walnuts because I didn’t have them, added cinnamon, and baked in an 8x8 pan because I have NO IDEA where my loaf pans are. Tasty, tasty! Wasn’t super dense like most recipes (possibly the sour cream?), and had that yummy caramelized crust. Put some butter on it and ate three pieces before it cooled all the way. If I made it exactly as printed, I’m sure it’d be fan-effin-tastic!

text:
Turns out perfect every time! 
FOR VEGANS:
Substitute the butter one-for-one with canola oil and substitute the sour cream one-for-one with canned full-fat coconut milk. I only used the thick fatty part of the coconut milk that sits on top of the liquid.

userID:

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7281893.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is identical to 'Valerie's Sour Cream Banana Bread' as published in 1987 in 'The American Country Inn and Bed & Breakfast Cookbook' except that Valerie's recipe calls for 1 cup of mashed bananas (much more precise than 2 regular bananas, sliced) and creaming the butter and sugar. This has been my 'go to' banana bread recipe for nearly 20 years...it just works every single time and is the best banana bread recipe.  That being said, I have used one that called for 1/2 cup of oil but it always had a slightly greasy texture to it which might happen by melting the butter as Janet's Banana Bread calls for.
Review:

5

I actually made this recipe twice, first melting the butter then combining it with the butter and slicing the bananas. Lastly mashing the bananas instead of slicing is a must!

text:
This banana bread recipe is one of the best I’ve ever had. Perfect color, smells amazing and tastes PHENOMENAL. I did add an extra half a banana with a few dashes of cinnamon and nutmeg for some extra “pop”. Just a helpful hint, even if you grease your pan, the sticky dough like to stay in it after it cooks, so let it cool IN the pan for a few prior to putting it on the cooling racks. One of mine somewhat “exploded” from the inside out when trying to remove it while still hot (see pic).

text:
I won’t use this recipe again. I know I’m in the minority in not giving it a high rating. I followed it to an absolute “T” except that I mashed the bananas. I baked it in a temperature-verified 350 degree gas oven in a Pampered Chef stoneware loaf pan. It took an hour and five minutes for the center to set up, and it got very dark brown in that amount of time. It’s super-sweet, too sweet, and something isn’t allowing the banana flavor to come out as much as it should. Disappointing. I’ll go back to my standby recipe in my old Betty Crocker cookbook, which has been perfect every time for over 40 years for me.

text:
I've made this twice now. The first time I used sliced almonds instead of walnuts, which I prefer. I also left out the sour cream. It was really good but not that banana-y. The second time I added an extra 1/2 banana, and the next time I'll probably use 3 instead of 2. ALSO, a great touch to this is to add some honey. You can substitute some honey for some sugar, only using 1/2 cup or so of sugar. If you don't want to bake honey into it, drizzle it on top. So good.

text:
Great recipe that required absolutely no altering in my opinion. I used bananas which I had previously tossed in the freezer as they were getting over-ripe and it turned out great.  Moist and rich.  

This last batch used small loaf pans because my previous attempt turned out slightly under-baked larger loafs.  It could have been my oven or the convection setting.  Regardless, smaller dark metal loaf pans worked great.  I also tested using both cooking spray against Crisco & flour.  Both resulted in non-stick loafs however the cooking spray was a bit more moist (damp).  If you have the time, grease & flour the pans.

I changed the flour to Bob’s Red Mill 1 to 1 gluten free flour because of DS’ diet. I made muffins instead of a loaf, swapped sour cream with greek yogurt, upped the mashed bananas to 4 and reduced the sugar to 3/4. It’s still very sweet. Perhaps next time I will change to maple syrup as suggested by others. Oh and I baked it at 330F for 25 mins in a convection oven. Came out perfectly golden and fluffy.

text:
I don't generally review because I end up modifying the recipes, but I've made this one several times - pretty much as written. I do add 3 mashed bananas (don't change any of the other ingredients measurements) and a little ground clove. Other than that, exactly as written. Also, make sure a toothpick comes out clean from the very center of the loaf. Otherwise it will be undercooked. I've never heard people rave so much and ask for the recipe when I share the bread I make. It's EXTREMELY moist and wonderful. The sour cream makes all the difference in the world!

text:
I have tried a lot of banana bread recipes through my 45+ years of baking and this is by far the best. For me this is a classic. One of those recipes you pass on to the next generations, it's that good.  For starters it doesn't call for oil which I have never been a fan of oily bread.  The bread is very tender with excellent texture. I made one change, I mashed the bananas. I had made it previously adding sliced bananas as directed but I wasn't fond of mushy chunks in the bread.  Have also substituted mini chocolate chips for the nuts as the mood struck.

userID:
22028534
Display Name:
La Maison Rose 
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
30
favoritesCount:
124
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4573765.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's sooo.... good and very moist!  I doubled the recipe ... I used 4 very ripened bananas - MASHING the bananas .... will distribute the banana flavours and texture through out the whole bread versus slicing. I did some adjustments  ... I softened the butter instead of melting it.   I seldom have sour cream on hand but always have yogurt of some kind in the fridge, so I decided on using strawberry yogurt.   I halved the amount of walnuts and added 1 cup of defrosted strawberries, making sure they were well drained and then sliced into quarters.  I made sure  the bananas were completely incorporated into the batter before I carefully folded in the strawberries.   By adding strawberries, I did have to make baking time adjustments  -  approx. 70-75 mins .   Will bake this again and again!
This section has been amended ... Just made this the 2nd time only I made it GF for my daughter.   I used a GF flour blend of rice flour and tapioca flour 1:1 ratio to what is called for in the recipe ... I made the same changes as above ... only cutting the baking by 5 mins.  It came out just as moist and great tasting as the regular flour!  ... would of never guested it was GF .

text:
Excellent and no harm in adding an additional banana if that's your preference. The sour cream makes the bread incredibly moist and whether you SLICE or MASH is truly IRRELEVANT as long as the bananas are appropriately ripened.  Bananas that have matured in the refrigerator for several days to  the point of baby food consistence will render the best bread, and this holds true for any recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe today and it is very good.  Although the bananas were a bit mushy in the finished product.  Think I will stay with my recipe which I have been making for many many years. This recipe calls for “folding” the sour cream and bananas  in last.  My recipe calls for adding bananas to batter in the mixer and giving it a couple of turns which incorporates the banana more evenly throughout the batter, then fold in the dry ingredients.  I prefer this method—no mushy spots in bread.

text:
I made this before reading any of the reviews. Followed the recipe except no nuts and mashed the bananas instead of slicing them. Turned out a little  dark and crispy on the edges, so since I used glass pans I will turn down the temp 25 degrees. Banana chunks turned purple in the bread, so I will  probably whirl in the processor and I might cut the sugar down and add spice like cinnamon and nutmeg  next time.

text:
Followed the recipe pretty much spot on. Used a bit more flour, walnuts and bananas. About 1/4 cup more flour because i used more bananas. This was my first time baking banana nut bread and it is super delicious. I also had to adjust the bake time and temp to compensate for my electric oven. During the first 30 minutes, i could smell the bread was cooking fast. So i turned the oven down to 300 and cooked for about 45 more minutes. It turned out perfect for me. Nice and crisp on outside and moist and fluffy on the inside.

text:
BEST BANANA BREAD I’VE EVER HAD! This so delicious but I did make a few changes. 1. Instead of slicing the bananas, purée them in a blender. This gives banana flavor to every bite while slicing them gives flavor to only some bites. 2. It does make one loaf which isn’t a lot. Make a double batch! I do every time and am happy. Note: if you are not into sweet, moist breads than this is not for you. Very sweet and moist.

I made one loaf as-directed for freezing - came out perfect - and I made a second loaf, identical, but I baked it with a topping spread over the top of the batter before I put it in the oven, made out of melted butter, brown sugar, crushed walnuts, and cinnamon. Turned out beautifully using a mix of the  recommended adjustments. I used plain yogurt instead of sour cream, put less sugar and did half brown and half white. Room temp eggs and softened the butter. I beat the butter/sugar, beat the egg in, sifted the dry ingredients and folded in the rest. Be warned, it takes a while to prep!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe worked beautifully! I really wanted some banana bread and didn't have all the ingredients so I made a few substitutions: I didn't want walnuts so I added 1/2 teaspoon of hazelnut extract, 1/4 cup of flaxseeds, and 1/4 cup of finely shredded coconut. I wanted to make it vegetarian so instead of sour cream I used 1/2 cup of coconut cream and 1/2 teaspoon of lemon juice. I also reduced the amount of sugar by half, using 1/4 cup of brown sugar and 1/4 cup of white sugar and used an additional banana. With these changes I got a fluffy, ridiculously moist bread. This will definitely be my go-to recipe from now on.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this 3 times now.  The first 2 times I made it as the recipe states and it is delicious.  This time I changed it up a bit.  I had 3 over ripe bananas that I used.  I also melted my butter in a 2 qt sauce pan and when it was melted I took it off the fire and stirred in the sugars.  Then I dropped in the bananas whole and used my potato masher to get the consistency I wanted then added the eggs (because it had cooled off by then) and the vanilla.  I mixed in the flour mixture, stirring until it was integrated well and then the sour cream along with the walnuts and the extra addition of a couple tablespoons each of dried cranberries and sunflower meats.  It turned out perfectly delicious.  I would and still do trying the original recipe!

I read a tip elsewhere on this site to bake banana bread one notch below the middle notch in the oven.  Also to put aluminum foil (shiny side down) over the top for the last twenty minutes of baking.  I did those two things.  It was very tasty.

It really is a 5 star recipe! The only things I did different were, I mashed the bananas, because I couldn't imagine biting into a piece of banana bread and feeling something wet and squishy in my mouth! Haha... And instead of butter, I used coconut oil, because I substitute all butter and shortening and oil products with coconut oil. Also, I didn't have sour cream, so I used blueberry greek yogurt! The bread was delish!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, as it needed minor tweaking. I replaced the butter with canola oil. When I made it with butter it came out a bit on the dry side. With oil it was amazingly moist. I also added a teaspoon of lemon or orange  zest. And I heated 2 tablespoons water and added  1 tablespoons sugar until dissolved. Brush bread with this piping hot out of the oven every 5 mins or so until used up. It makes for a moist sweet beautiful top worthy of cook book page glossy.  This is a keeper with the minor tweaking.

None
text:
I am not a baker but have made this twice & it disappeared in couple of days. I made some minor adjustments based on reviews. 
Let butter soften at room temp ( do not melt)
Mash bananas - I don't measure them as I like lots of banana flavor here
3/4 cup sugar
1/4 cup yogurt (vs sour cream)
1 tsp. each of baking soda and baking powder
1-3/4 cup flour

text:
This recipe is awesome and based on the other reviews it is very flexible. I followed many of the suggestions.  These were the adjustments I made.

Creamed the Butter
1 tsp of lemon juice
1 tsp of Baking soda & Baking powder
1/8 tsp of Nutmeg
1/4 tsp Cinnamon
I used heaping cups of the measurement listed for the flour
just  a little over 1 cup of mashed bananas.

Next time I will use the exact recipe to see if I notice any major difference. I immediately had 2 slices. My husband was upset I didn't want to share :)

text:
Ugh...why are people making so many changes to an already perfect recipe!? It baffles me.  Anyway, I made this AS DIRECTED and it's the best banana bread I ever made.  I used to make another one that's saved in my favorites from this site but that one was so heavy and dense.  I like this one better because it's much lighter and is still packed with flavor. I watched the video first and they mash the bananas in the video so I did that and I'm glad I did cuz I see from the reviews that if you don't do that, they get mushy.  I didn't know how it was going to turn out because of using melted butter, but it still turned out amazing.  This one's a keeper!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for the first time with some modifications and it was moist and delicious! I made the following substitutions: 1/2 cup extra light testing olive oil in place of the butter; 1/2 cup greek yogurt in place of the sour cream; 1/2 cup Splenda Blend for Baking in place of the sugar; and 1 1/8 cups Namaste gluten-free flour in place of the flour. I baked it in a convection oven @325 degrees for one hour and 10 minutes.  This will be my new recipe for banana bread!

text:
I hate to review a recipe I altered, but this is a very good banana bread! As for altering it, I mashed the bananas rather than slicing them. I spit-balled the amount of butter as all I had was a block of butter. But I've baked enough to know what 1/2 cup looks like. I used half brown sugar/half white, totaling just under a full cup. I added some Kahlua because I add it to a lot of things I make - lol. And I didn't have any nuts so I added chocolate chips, because why not? I think the addition of the sour cream is what does the trick (or maybe it was the Kahlua?). In any case this will become my go-to banana bread, though next time I probably won't bake it on a whim so I'll have some walnuts at the ready. I'll still use brown sugar, chocolate chips, and Kahlua though.  :)

text:
His is probably the best banana bread I've made! I did tweak it a little. First of all, I had three bananas to use so I multiplied the recipe by 1.5. Also I didn't have my 9.5in loaf pan, so I used three mini loaf pans and baked at 350 for 45 min. I used plain nonfat Greek yogurt instead of sour cream and then figured that the regular sour cream it called for had fat, so I added abt a tbsp of melted coconut oil. It was perfectly moist on the inside and the edges were sweet and just slightly crispy. My family couldn't stop eating it!

This was the best ever...I'm not a fan of banana bread but I will be making only this recipe.  Changes I made....1/2 cup of white and 1/2 cup brown sugar. 1 cup whole wheat flour and 1/2 cup white flour. I used plain yogurt instead of sour cream. I mashed my bananas and used 3 instead of 2 and added some cinnamon.  I also added chocolate chips and want to try the recipe again without since I ink it took away from the awesomeness of the bread. I baked for an hour and 10 minutes. My husband said it tasted like pudding it was so moist

text:
I'll def make this again. I did change the recipe a bit to make it more healthy: I used Splenda instead of sugar, and I used 1 cup of whole wheat flour with 1/2 cup of white flour, instead of all white flour. I didn't have walnuts, but pecans were a very tasty alternative. I also added approximately 1/4 cup of wheat germ and 1/4 tsp of cinnamon to the mixture. Before baking, I topped with a sprinkle of cinnamon and sugar. My oven always bakes hot, so I only baked for 48 min. Perfection. Very moist. Thank you!

text:
I used bread flour instead of all-purpose flour, which gave it a better texture. I used vanilla yogurt instead of sour cream. I also added a layer of semi-sweet chocolate chips to the top of the batter (after being poured in the pan.) The chips slowly sank into the batter while baking, creating a rich, almost crisp and chewy chocolate "bonus" layer on top. So delicious!

text:
This was terrific! Very moist and a wonderful banana taste. I did not change any of the ingredients but I did however change the way I assembled it. I didn't melt the butter but softened it to room temperature. I creamed the sugar with the butter then mixed in the eggs and vanilla.  Whisked all the dry ingredients together and beat into the wet ingredients until just combined. I mashed the bananas completely and folded them in along with the sour cream and nuts. It took one hour and ten minutes to bake.

text:
I really liked it. Although, I did tweak it a little  and it came out great. First, I mashed the bananas. The thought of them sliced eating them cooked- doesn't sound to pleasant. I also added about half a tablespoon of cinnamon. It really makes a difference. Also, since my mom is allergic to walnuts I just did it without so she could eat it too. I also beat the mixture instead of stirring it so it'd become a little more fluffy while cooked. Overall, this was a great recipe and my parents loved it! I'll definitely be making it again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wanted to make banana bread and my old recipe is so mediocre, so I googled, “best banana bread recipe ever” and this one came up. In prior years, I have had luck using the same search words for rolled sugar cookie dough...”best rolled sugar cookies ever”.. anyway, I got it then and I got it now when I wanted banana bread. This is so moist and luscious and super easy! I do add the chopped walnuts, they really make the bread, but I even went one step further and added 1/2 cup white chocolate chips. You can’t see them in the bread, but you say to yourself, “OMG! This is so frickin’ good!” Hubby doesn’t want any other cake now, just this! I also add dark chocolate chips and it’s great! So, you must make it, and others will want the recipe, too! Thank you JANET!

text:
This is the best and most moist Banana Bread I have ever made. After reading all the reviews I did make some changes. I mashed my Banana instead of slicing it and I only softened the butter instead of totally melting it. I also added 1/2 c of semi sweet chocolate chips just for that extra touch of indulgence. Everyone loved it. This will be my new go to Banana Bread recipe.

I followed Naples review and added baking powder, lemon juice, used soft butter (not melted) and mashed the bananas.  This bread is by far the best banana bread I've ever made - and I've tried dozens of recipes!  My only complaint is that my loaves fell after removing from oven.  They tested as done and I even cooked them longer than called for.....will try again making smaller loaves.

text:
This is the best banana bread recipe I have ever found.  It is dense and early on I had trouble with it being a bit gooey in the middle after an hour baking.  I have discovered that if I turn off the oven after an hour and just let it sit in the oven for 20-30 minutes, it is perfect.  The outside takes on a bit of crispness that makes the bread even better and no gooey center!

text:
This crumble topping is a MUST for this delicious recipe! Makes this the all-time perfect banan bread! And I've made them ALL! 

1/2 stick melted butter
1/4 cup sugar
1/2 cup flour
1/2 cup finely chopped walnuts
Combine ingredients, layer on top of banana bread before baking.

text:
Absolutely the best banana bread recipe ever!!!
So moist.
I used 3 large mashed bananas and added cinnamon, nutmeg and a little ginger.
Used about 1 1/2 t vanilla flavoring.
Followed  reviewers  suggestions and  used 1 t baking soda and 1 t baking powder with 1 3/4 c flour.
Used pecans instead of walnuts and added 3/4 c semisweet chocolate morsels.
I'm always asked to make more!!
Yummy!!

I've been making this for a few years now.   I do not put in the walnuts because I serve it at various functions and want to be mindful of those with allergies.  The only modifications I make are to use 3 bananas instead of 2,  I mash them instead of slicing, and I cut the sugar back to 3/4 cup.   This always gets rave reviews and requests for the recipe.

I made this exactly as directed with the exception of using pecans instead of walnuts. It was fantastic!!! The only thing I would do differently would be to mash the bananas. text:
The banana bread is very yummy! Instead of slicing the bananas, I mashed mine, but otherwise I followed the recipe exactly. Unfortunately, the batter started oozing and leaking/spilling over my bread pan and didn't stop until it had been in the oven for an hour. I ended up having to bake it about 1 hr 25 minutes total, and the top turned out more crunchy than I would have preferred, but lo and behold my boyfriend loved the crunch! He said it reminded him of a banana cookie. I think in the future I will split the batter between two bread pans, but I look forward to making this again.

userID:
1389869
Display Name:
SPARKLER8666
isPro:

96
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
MODIFIED:   I always use whole wheat white flour which I increased to 1 and 3/4 cups, and increased the baking powder by a quarter tsp, and I watch my sugar so I used a quarter cup of Splenda brown and a half cup of white sugar. I liked the idea of a tang of flavor from the lemon one person recommended, but I didn't have lemons so I added a bit of fresh squeezed mandarin orange juice and a bit of the zest finely grated as well. I always add chocolate chips to banana, pumpkin and zucchini bread, so I added 2/3 cup of semi sweet chocolate chips. Also I baked them as muffins because I was hungry and wanted them faster. Also I forgot to add the eggs. I decided to mix all the wet stuff together and all the dry stuff together and then slowly add the dry into the wet with a whisk. It worked beautifully, I just forgot the eggs. Anyway, despite all these modifications the  final result was a tender, yummy and not too heavy banana chocolate chip muffin. (By the way, I added the chocolate chips into the dry mixture before adding it to the wet. The flour coating keeps them from sinking to the bottom.)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time at making a dessert.  I had some ripe bananas and just thought about not wanting to throw them out.  This is an easy bake to make.  My only variations were:
I used three banana because they were small; I like many others mashed up the bananas; I only used 1/2 cup of sugar because of the sweet bananas; I added 1/4 tsp of cinnamon and 1/4 tsp of nutmeg; and I used sea salt rather than table salt; used 1/2 tsp of baking soda and 1/2 tsp of baking power.  My cooking time was 53 minutes at 350 degrees.  Bread was just right.  Be sure and wait until it is completely cooled to make cutting easy.  Love the taste.

It turned out beautifully. For those who have banana issues, here's a tip-freeze the bananas. When you are ready to make this, thaw them completely at room temp. They will be much sweeter and wonderfully mushy. They will incorporate into your batter like a dream.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of the best banana bread recipes I've tried. Super moist and not too sweet. It's quick and simple. I followed the recipe for the ingredients and cook time, minus the walnuts. I did slice my bananas, but only to throw it into the mix and have my mixer blend/crush them into the batter (think it's the best way to get the most banana flavor out of it). Also, had to bake it an additional 20 minutes as the test poke didn't come out clean at the 1hr mark (could be my oven). Other than that, my family loves it. Will make again in the future. Great way to utilize over-riped bananas. Highly recommend this recipe.

text:
The bread is moist and has a good flavor. Great with honey butter and morning coffee. I made this recipe as written.   I did not give it 5 stars, as another recipe that is favored by my family calls for more bananas (mashed).

A note on all the reviews submitted that mention tweaks, etc.  - those are different recipes and not a true critique of this recipe.   Akin to reviewing a tomato soup recipe, but the cook  tweaked it and used squash instead -  it's not the same tomato soup recipe.   

Let's keep it real.

The best recipe I've found. I receive tons of compliments every time I make it. I follow the recipe as us with only two variations: 1. Use only 1/4 cup of sour cream, it comes out too moist with 1/2 and 2. Purée the bananas, sliced will only turn dark in the bread, not very appetizing.

text:
I absolutely love this recipe.  I made it exactly as written and it is delicious!  I am making a gluten free version this morning. The only substitution being made is (1+1/2 cups of Bob's Red Mill all-purpose gluten free flour with 2+1/4 tsp xanthan gum added) in place of the (1+1/2 cups regular all-purpose flour).  Making this minor substitution turns this recipe into the BEST gluten free banana bread I have ever eaten.  My gluten free friends love it!

This bread is delicious!  I can't get my husband to stop eating it.  He seldom reacts that way! 

I really appreciate a large recipe like this one.  Makes four loaves and that gives me one for us, and three to either freeze for later or to share with friends, family or neighbors.  Perfect.

I loved the preparation of the pans!  I've never done that before but what a wonderful treat to have the sides and bottom of the bread lightly coated with sugar and cinnamon!    Also liked the vanilla in the mix.  A very nice, moist and delicious bread!
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I also made this recipe one day when I didn't have enough sour cream so I used what I had (about half of what the recipe calls for) and then added Applesauce which gave the bread the needed moisture and also a wonderful bit of extra flavor.

text:
I made this bread yesterday and it was AMAZING!!!!! It is the first time I have ever made bread and I really thought it would take a couple times to master a good bread but I was wrong. First time was a charm and a hit for the whole family. I did read reviews and changed a couple of things. I creamed the r.t. butter with sugar rather than melted butter. I also used 1/2 cup low fat vanilla yogurt rather than sour cream, mashed the bananas, and added 1/2 tsp cinnamon. Lastly, I used my mixer for the entire batter. After making it this way there is NOTHING I would change for other batches. I still can't believe that I actually made this bread. WOW!!!! Thank you for the recipe and everyone who offered tweaking tips. AGAIN... WOW!!!!!

It stayed ripe and delicious and fresh tasting even after I doubled, and froze a loaf.

text:
I've been making banana bread for so many years, however since the kids are grown I don't make like I use to. And when I did start back making & using my old recipe  not everyone ate it, and it was soon thrown out. Boy when I gave this a try it was gone in 2-3 days. I did tweek a little like adding a couple dashes of cinnamon, about 2 Tab. oil. What caught my attention to this recipe was only 2 bananas which was how many I had. Since I've made banana bread so often I didn't even pay attention that the recipe said slice the bananas.(i was so use to mashing mine up & did) As some reviwers said they didn't like them sliced. If I use my  hand mixer I simply put my bananas in a small bowl and beat them with the mixer to get them mashed up. Overall this bread with the added sour cream was the best I had made in a long time. And was super, super moist!!!!! Just the right banana taste!!!!! Will be making again!!!!! (3-10-2017)

text:
These were very moist and delicious. I substituted coconut oil for butter, brown sugar for white sugar, and lime yogurt for sour cream. I also excluded the nuts, and mashed the bananas instead of slicing them. I added 1/4 t. cinnamon and 1/16 t. nutmeg. I baked them as little mini loaves, for about 25 mins at 350. Will try with some cocoa powder next time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best banana bread recipe I have come across so far.  It has a lot of flavor and is nice and moist.   I did tweak the recipe a bit, in that I didn't quite melt the butter, but instead softened it and mixed it with the sugar first.  Then added vanilla, eggs (mixed well), and even sour cream (but I actually subbed in plain greek yogurt because I was curious... it worked well!).  I then folded in dry ingredients and mashed banana (not sliced, I do not prefer large chunks).  I didn't have nuts so I subbed in semi-sweet chocolate chips.  YUM. OH, and I set it for 50 minutes at first because I always like to check in on my baked goods early.  Didnt take much longer than that to be done.   I am actually saving this recipe and will be my go-to for banana bread.  Thank you!

userID:
7807859
Display Name:
Jbnewburg
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

22

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4516874.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You can use greek yogurt or sour cream.  I cut the sugar to a  1/2  or 2/3 cup when using really sweet fruit. I also have swapped out the 2 bananas to either 1 banana and some blueberries, strawberries, peaches or even butternut squash so long as the total pureed fruit mixture measures between 1 to 1 1/2 cups.  In addition to the 1/2 C chopped nuts, one could substitute or add to a hand full of dried blueberries, cranberries or cherries. Make it with what you have and/have on hand. My 14 and 16 year olds love this recipe as muffins. Handy as a lunch box snack. Lastly, I add between 1/4 to 1/2  C  oatmeal for additional fiber.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I've made it many times with and without the modifications suggested by other reviewers. The recipe as originally posted gives out a delicious 5-star bread but, as pointed by others, it will be weird looking. Mash, not slice, the bananas. To get a fluffier bread, use 1 tsp each baking powder and baking soda. And soften and cream the butter rather than melt it. It will rise so much a 9x5 loaf pan will not contain it, I get a loaf and 4-5 muffins from the recipe as modified.

text:
I've made this twice, once as directed and second with variations. Both times I added an extra banana and mashed them, second time I froze and thawed them. (Btw, frozen bananas look disgusting, but make great flavor!) I replaced quarter of the white sugar with brown. I also replaced most of the sour cream with vanilla Greek yogurt, so I reduced the vanilla in half. Then I used a combo of walnuts and pecans. Cook times always depend on the pan size and oven so I go by smell and don't rely on the directed time. Turned out really good both times! Best banana bread I've ever had!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This review is actually my personal notes, so that I remember what I did to make this recipe perfect:

-  Use 1 cup of bananas and DON'T slice them. It's better if you mash them. 

- Don't "melt" your butter. Use @ room temperature.

-  Use a mixer to cream the butter and sugar first.

- slightly beat eggs before slowing adding them to the batter. 

-  Ad tsp of cinnamon and lemon juice.

- use 1/4 cup  more flour than the recipe calls for

- instead of 1 cup of just white sugar...use 3/4 white and 1/4 brown

text:
This was probably the best banana bread I've ever made. HOWEVER, a couple differences. I mashed up the bananas, not 100% as there were some chunks of banana that were left. And I used about half of brown sugar as well as white. 60 mins at 350 was not nearly enough. I had it in the oven for almost a half hour extra and it was perfect. Not too dark on the outside and still light on the inside. I don't know if it's because I mashed up the bananas and used brown sugar that made it have to cook longer? Either way it turned out great.  Using this recipe from now on!

text:
This recipe is quick and delicious, just the way it is.  However, I only had one very ripe banana, which I mashed very easily.  I had some blueberries and raspberries to use up; so I  added about 1/4 cup sugar and cooked the berries on the stove top just to boiling.  Let this cool completely and added about 2/3 cup to the banana bread mixture.  Then, I reduced the 1 cup of sugar to 1/4 cup.   Also, I used plain yogurt instead of sour cream.  It was delicious and really filled my house with wonderful aromas.  TV Foster.

text:
A great base recipe. I mash the bananas instead of putting them in whole (personal preference) and I add cinnamon and nutmeg too. I use greek yogurt instead of sour cream (substituted 1:1) to make it a little healthier and it works great. Very moist. Cooking time for my oven is too long, I suggest cutting the time in half and checking as you go to be sure it isn't over cooked.

text:
This is the BEST banana bread I've ever made or had!

A few things were changed up a little.

1) I'm at altitude so I cut the butter by 1 tbsp, added 2 tbsp of water, and lowered the baking temp to 325. 

2) Didn't add walnuts.

3) Mashed two bananas, previously frozen. 

4) Sprinkled cinnamon in at the end. 

5) Used a 9-inch pie pan because I forgot I ditched old loaf pans and haven't replaced them!

The BEST!

text:
Love this recipe! Made some changes, mostly due to a depleted pantry. Subbed vanilla bean Greek yogurt for the sour cream. And used 1/2 c sugar and 1/2 c brown sugar. And like many others, I mashed the bananas and used three not two. I like the intense flavor and I needed to use them. At the suggestion of another reviewer I also added a tsp of baking powder. For my own taste, I added about 3 tsp cinnamon and 1 1/2 tsp cloves. This banana bread is so moist and full of flavor, it's perfect for breakfast or afternoon tea.

I tried this recipe the best banana bread. Very moist and light. I added Nutella chocolate spread by mixing 2Tbls of Nutella with some sour cream. Put half the batter in the loaf tin then added the Nutella and then added the rest of the batter. It came out beautiful. ??????????used a knife to cut through the batter before to put the batter into the oven. I used pecans instead of walnuts as walnuts were not available.

It's great, though I think it needs more nuts!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4284648.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best recipe for banana bread! I've searched for banana bread recipes with all the same results- too dry! Not this recipe! The banana bread I made was to die for! It was moist, delicious, and the aroma of bananas was out of this world. (I used 3) Do not use a blender or mixer. Mix it by hand, melt the butter, mash the bananas and watch it closely while it is baking. I did not cover it with foil to prevent over browning. Also, use a regular aluminum pan. Do not use glass or a dark non-stick pan. All ovens are slightly different. I baked my loaf for 70 minutes@ 325 on convection bake (gas stove). Thanks for sharing this absolutely awesome recipe!
Review:

text:
In all the years I have been baking I never had banana bread that was this tasty  as well as moist.  It was the best banana bread I have ever had and I will continue to use this recipe.  I baked it at 350 for 40 minutes then dropped the temp to 325 for the last 20 minutes.  It was perfect in looks , texture and taste.  I didn't slice the bananas but chopped them into pieces about the size of malted milk balls..  Thank You for sharing the recipe!!  5* doesn't do it justice!!

text:
I've made this several times now and it has turned out pretty well every time.  I do make one substitution, because we always have it on hand and we rarely ever buy sour cream, and that is to use Lime Greek yogurt in its place. I usually find it takes around 80 minutes to get done rather than the recommended 60. In addition to the normal loaf,  I just made it into 48 mini-muffins and all I did was shorten the baking time and they turned out well. If you try this,  you can fill the muffin tins pretty full.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe several times and always get rave reviews. Sometimes I use 2 bananas, other times I use 3. I firmly believe the key to a nice, rich banana flavor is to use overly ripe bananas. I wait until the outer skin on the bananas is very spotted and the fruit very soft or squishy. My husband is sure they need to be thrown out at this point, but they are perfect for this recipe. I, like other reviewers, like to mash the bananas before adding to the other ingredients and add 1/4-1/2 tsp cinnamon. Delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! The only difference that I do is I blend the banana and sour cream together after I mash the banana with a fork. Then I take that mixture and add it in with everything else and have everything thoroughly blended as a whole.  I tried it as the recipe stated the first time and like others said the texture was a bit off and there were chunks of banana so the flavor wasn't consistent.   Mashing the banana and blending everything together with a mixer makes everything come together perfectly. I make this once or twice a month and it's a staple in our house.

text:
This has been a fav so far.  The batter was very thick following the directions exactly so I added one mashed banana (since I had an extra).  It turned out beautifully.  I love the sliced or chunks of banana in the finished bread.  Though practically unnoticeable visually, it's a nice, palatable surprise to have spots of added moistened flavor in a bite.  I do think the third mashed banana was essential for texture, moisture and flavor.  It baked up beautifully but did require an additional 10 minutes.  This is a keeper.

country:
None
text:
This was absolutely delicious, but mostly because I followed the advice of the reviewer that said mush the bananas, add both baking soda and baking powder, and do a full cup of banana.  Two bananas only yielded 3/4 a cup so I did three bananas to make the full cup. Also, 350° made the crust on my loaf like a rock so I turned it down to 325° and had to cook it a little longer to save the loaf. I cut away some of the nasty edges and the end result was delicious. Simply delicious. 4 stars because of all the necessary changes the original recipe needed. 5 stars for the helpful reviewer's version.

This is the best banana bread recipe, it has amazing flavor and great light texture. I did mash the bananas together with the sugar,  cinnamon, vanilla and nutmeg. Everyone wanted seconds, even the finicky grown ups. Thanks for posting :)

city:

country:
None
text:
This recipe is great, although I will admit to making a few adjustments... 
1. I mash the bananas as I, like may others, am not a fan of the strange texture the sliced bananas have in the finished product; 
2. I use 1 TBSP of vanilla rather than a tsp. It was a happy accident while baking one morning before my coffee had taken effect; 
3. I substitute the sour cream with a 1/2 C of banana yogurt. It keeps the banana bread nice and moist while adding a little more banana flavor.

text:
Best banana bread I have ever made, hands down! And I have made a LOT of banana bread using different recipes. It is so moist and delicious! The color is beautiful when it comes out of the oven. I did change the process  of how I prepared the batter...I creamed SOFTENED butter with the sugar instead of adding melted butter. Also, I mashed the bananas rather than just slice them because I wanted to ensure the banana flavor was throughout the bread. I added a tsp of baking powder and a half tsp of cinnamon, too. Baked for exactly 60 minutes and it turned out perfectly. This is my go-to banana bread recipe from now on. Thank you!

text:
This is the foundation of a great banana bread. In my opinion you can experiment with it if you want. I think the bananas should be mashed instead of sliced and that substituting some brown sugar for some of the white will give it a richer more complex flavor. Adding some cloves or allspice will also make the bread more unique. I have book marked this recipe and my second loaf is baking as I type this. How many times have you tasted a subpar and dry banana bread? You will not be that person if you use this recipe :)

text:
This is my go-to recipe (with a few modifications).  I was advised by the best baker I know to always add an extra banana to any banana bread recipe I try, so I use 3 *mashed* bananas.  I only made it with *sliced* bananas once, and the texture was so mushy and odd that my kids (who love banana bread) wouldn't touch it.  I also bake it in 3 mini (5x2.5x2) loaf pans for exactly 45 minutes.

text:
I made the following changes as suggested by a previous reviewer. 1 & 3/4 c white flour, 1 tsp baking powder with 1 tsp baking soda, 1/8 tsp salt. I sifted the dry ingredients together. I creamed the butter with the sugar, then added the 2 large beaten eggs, 1 tsp vanilla, 1 tsp lemon juice and the sour cream folded into the wet ingredients. Then mixed, by hand, the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients. Oh I also added just a pinch of Indonesian cinnamon.  And 1/2 cup of rough chopped walnuts...my husband loves walnuts. Me too!

text:
I am a fan of banana bread and I really liked how the sour cream made this one moist and added a bit of a lighter note to the taste. I used as much sugar as the recipe called for, but made it half white sugar and half packed dark brown sugar. It makes the banana bread a little richer in flavor. Also, I lightly mashed the bananas, (so they were still a bit chunky), instead of slicing them because it didn't sound good to bite into a piece of very ripe banana.

text:
I found the recipe easy to follow. I only gave the original recipe 4 stars because I did make some minor changes as I saw suggested by another lady. The changes are that I creamed the butter with the sugar rather than melting the butter, I added 1 tsp of lemon juice with the vanilla, used 1 tsp each of baking soda and baking powder, and 1 3/4 cups of flour. The last minor change was that I mashed my bananas instead of slicing them. The loaf turned out wonderfully moist and my whole family enjoyed it. I definitely have a new favourite banana bread recipe!??

userID:
15657330
Display Name:
tynee
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
125
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time making a banana bread and it was very easy and very delicious. My mom used to make banana bread all the time when I was a little kid and I remember eating it all day everyday. Now I'm all grown up I've been wanting to give it a try to make it myself. So I followed this recipe and just changing only 4 things. First, I used brown sugar instead of white sugar. Second, I used 3 bananas instead of 2 thinking maybe it will give more banana flavor (I was just experimenting). Third, I smashed the bananas instead of slicing them (I followed the suggestion of the other reviewers). Maybe next time I'll try to slice them instead of smashing just to see the difference. Lastly, I baked it for 1 hour and 15 minutes. To be honest, first I set my timer to 50 minutes on 350 degrees just in case so I can check on it and it was pretty obvious that it wasn't ready yet. So I added another 10 minutes, which was on the recipe. After 10 minutes, I checked it again and it wasn't still ready so I added another 10 minutes. I believe it was okay at that moment but I wasn't satisfied so I added another 5 minutes and it was finally done. So the other reviewers were right about baking it for an hour and 15 minutes and then let it sit for about 10-20 minutes before slicing them. It was very delicious and super moist and my boyfriend loved it! It was our dessert. He couldn't resist and he had 2 slices because it was really good and he also had it for breakfast. *NOTE: I used toothpick to check it i
Review:
Rating:
5

Janet's Rich Banana Bread Recipe was exceptionally tasty. I doubled the recipe, added 2 teaspoons of Vanilla Extract and mashed 3 bananas instead of slicing. 4. I also cut the sugar in half (wanted lightly sweetened bread, instead of cake) I felt that would be better. Melting the butter is an excellent idea. Those I shared my bread with said they could taste the butter while chewing. Each time I'd wake up during the night, I'd cut a small slither of it. It is irresistibly delicious... moist, tender, with just the right amount of banana flavor. Thank you Janet!

Sincerely Geri

I made some variations to this recipe to try to make it a bit healthier. I used 1/4 cup butter and 1/4 cup applesauce to lower the fat. I used a stevia/sugar blend instead of regular sugar. The results turned out great! Now I can enjoy it without feeling too guilty for eating a second slice. :)

text:
I stumbled on to this recipe a few years ago when I was looking for something to make with those last few "going bad" bananas.  This was so easy to put together and turned out extremely well. I think I have used this over 50 times since I found it!  My "tweaks" are that I added an extra banana and mashed them instead of slicing. I also have use Greek yogurt in place of the sour cream (when I realized mid-mixing that I didn't have any sour cream!) and it turned our wonderfully!  I have made it with and without the walnuts and both are delicious - A "must" recipe!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an easy recipe as well as delicious.  I spaced out when making this today and did not adjust for my high altitude. Despite the fallen middle, the bread was delicious - a slight crunch on the outside and moist on the inside.  It generally turns out much better than today's but I didn't hear any complaint from dh!  I do mash the bananas first, and decrease baking soda (+ baking powder) to 1/2 teaspoon - well except for today lol. For others at higher altitude, increase the oven temp a bit, do not over mix the batter and put in a cup of water in a separate ovenproof dish and don't forget to decrease the leavening hahaha.

text:
This recipe is simple and delicious.  :) Made a few minor alterations to the recipe: Added  3.9 oz of unsweetened, organic apple sauce (for moisture and added flavor), used 2 1/2 mashed browned bananas (for moisture and flavor) and 3/4 cup chocolate chips (Allergy to nuts).  In addition,  I  ended up having to make cooking time changes due to pan size. I used an 8X4, generic foil pan.  375F for 18 minutes, then 350F for 28 minutes = 46 minutes cooking time*. * If you find yourself in the same situation with pan size, cooking time may still vary depending on the pans material (glass vs metal), thickness and oven temperature settings.

text:
Live overseas--can't get sour cream.  However, unsweetened Greek yogurt is an excellent substitute (and makes me feel a bit more virtuous when I eat a second piece)!!  I use half pecans and half chocolate-chips to make it "fancy" when I want to send it in to the kids' school.  It is also a great way to use the one "bad" banana that always seems to go very brown before anyone will eat it!!  Just store them in your freezer.  When you are ready to make the bread, thaw them, cut off the tops and squeeze them out like toothpaste!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3898572.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used 1/2 cup of brown sugar, 3 mashed bananas (I froze them and thawed them), no salt because I melted salted butter, and 1 teaspoon of cinnamon.  I only used 1 tsp of baking powder. I did the rest of the instructions. After I mixed in 2 eggs and vanilla, I did add the sour cream, bananas, then walnuts, then I mixed in the flour with baking powder. I cooked the batter as muffins in the oven on the bottom rack for 25 minutes on 325.  It turned out really dense, not spongy. It is slightly more chewy than spongy, I think because eggs make it dense and maybe the sour cream. They are gray cupcakes and I had 12 of them. They still had banana squiggles in them, I wonder how those show up? Some weren't topped off though. I added a bit of milk to a low cupcake batter and it flattened out the top from being expanded and round. I still want more banana flavor in banana bread.

text:
When slicing doesn't sound like the right thing to do, you go ahead and mash the bananas! Ideally, they're so ripe you can't get slices.   
I have this in the oven right now. The modifications I made are: •room temperature butter • 1C light brown sugar • Greek yogurt stands in for sour cream • no nuts (picky 6yr old) •added a splash of vanilla extract  and a generous dash of cinnamon • 5 small over-ripe bananas which I beat into the the butter/sugar/eggs. 
•gray sea-salt (it's the salt I have) - everything else is as directed. 
The batter is delicious.
I'm enjoying a hot slice. Not bad at all.

text:
I have made this twice now and made some minor variations to the recipe. I took the advice of other reviews and added 1tsp lemon juice, used 1tsp baking soda AND 1tsp baking powder. I reduced the flour to 1 3/4 cup, and mashed the bananas instead of slicing. I used three medium sized bananas that I quick ripened (placed 3 bananas on a cookie sheet and baked until blackened about 30 minutes at 300 degrees). After they are ripened they slide out of the peels easily and mash easily. DO NOT SLICE the bananas.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4183459.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this but modified it quite a bit and it was very delicious, moist and flavorful. I opted to use ricotta because that is what I had on hand. I used brown sugar because I prefer its flavor over white sugar, put double the amount of vanilla, used coconut oil instead of butter and added some cinnamon. I put all the wet ingredients in a blender and blended on high, before adding the dry ingredients. I did substitute baking powder 1 teaspoon and added 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda. This made the crumb light and fluffy rather than a dense heavy bread. I also find the trick to really good banana bread to use bananas you honestly think should go in the garbage. The more overly ripe they are, the better flavor the bread will have. I will make this as a family staple in our home :)
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
Love this! Haven't made Banana bread in years! I did change it slightly, I know that's annoying. I creamed the butter and sugar. I used three bananas... Two of them I mixed up with the other moist ingredients and the third I cut in small pieces and added towards the end with the walnuts. I also only had reduced fat sour cream so I used some of that and the remainder I used Noosa coconut yogurt. I also used a little vanilla bean paste and the little almond extract. I put the batter into three small mini loaf pans. I cut the bake time down but checked it every so often. I wish I had kept better track of the time... The taste is fantastic!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So, I've made this bread several times now, with a couple of variations each time. Each time, I've mashed the bananas instead of slicing them. The first time I didn't have enough sour cream and just replaced it with a mix of sour cream and cream cheese. Then the next time I made it I replaced the walnuts with an equivalent amount of shelled chopped pistachios, and added 1/4 cup of dried coconut, and 1/4 cup of dried chopped pineapple. This time I'm adding a little more volume of the add ins, and an extra egg to hold it all together, and we're going to warm each slice up and toss a scoop of vanilla ice cream and some caramel drizzle over it. Every time I've used this recipe, it has completely disappeared the first day out of the oven. It's a huge hit with my family and super easy to make.

text:
Wow. definitely on my top 3 list for banana bread! super light and fluffy! mild banana flavor.
I took some of the suggestions. almost whipping the room temp butter (not melted) and sugar. then adding in the eggs. then adding in the yogurt-plain whole milk- (I subbed for sour cream). made this nice and fluffy before adding the flour, salt and baking soda. then the bananas (mashed not sliced).
I made muffins so adjustment cook time to 33 min for normal muffins and 36 min for ones with blueberries added.

I've made this twice and tweaked a few ingredients the 2nd time. I used self rising flour and cut out the baking soda. This abridged version was a recipe from my great gramma and one of my comfort foods as a child. Love it

This is the best banana bread I've ever made! It came out perfectly! https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6087253.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was awesome! Best banana bread I've made, but I changed a few slight things.  I used salted real cream butter(publix brand),  I used vanilla bean paste instead of extract, only about 1/4 to 1/3 c of sour cream(I eyed it) and I used 3 very ripe medium-ish bananas(about 6-7 inches in length, not very thick) I also mixed all wet ingredients together first (butter, sugar, eggs, vanilla, sour cream and bananas) after creaming that together I mixed in the flour mixture of flour, baking soda and salt, slowly (like you would when making cookies) Divided between two 9x5 loaf pans baked at 350 for 30 minutes and beautiful!! Best bread I've ever made. Oh and no nuts. :)

text:
Changes to the recipe per reviewer naples34102 ( see 8/17/2009 review )---

Using a portable electric mixer --- Cream the unsalted butter with the sugar.  Add 1 egg at a time.  
Add 1 teaspoon lemon juice to the mashed ripe bananas.
Add 1 teaspoon baking soda and 1 teaspoon baking powder to 1 -3/4 cup all-purpose flour.  

Bake at 350 for 60 minutes.

It was great! I only made a few changes 
I didn't have sour cream so I used 1/2 cup buttermilk instead. The other thing is I added one more cup flour (only because I used buttermilk) and I substituted the nuts for chocolate chips and added 2 teaspoons baking powder.  One big thing I did is add 3 bananas instead of 2. That made a big difference. I also made muffins  instead of a loaf, and only baked for 30 minutes. 
I will definitely be making this again!

text:
This was delicious! I have used this recipe many times and every time I make it to share it gets rave reviews. The only things I change is that I freeze my old bananas and take them out as needed for this recipe so I mash them instead of slicing. Freezing them breaks down the cells of the bananas and give it a really smooth consistency. I always double the recipe plus 1 extra banana and lastly, I add an extra 1/2 cup of walnuts because we love nuts.

text:
Perfect banana bread. Because of the sour cream, I added 1 tsp of baking powder,  and replaced the vanilla with maple extract (I often use maple rather than vanilla as it adds a "deeper" flavor with some recipes.) I mashed the bananas instead of slicing them. Like a previous reviewer noted, one cup of mashed bananas is the right amount for one loaf. No need to search for a better recipe. 
 
Also, I have made this using olive oil in place of butter and the results are identical. Perfection.

userID:
14435405
Display Name:
Sam G
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
3

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1538267.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe at least half a dozen times and it is my go to recipe for banana bread. Some revisions I make to suit my tastes: 2 large bananas or 3 medium, 1/2 cup of sugar instead of 1 cup,  2 tsp of cinnamon,  1 1/2 tsp of ground ginger, 1/2 tsp of cloves, 1/4 tsp of nutmeg. I would recommend using softened butter and creaming it with the sugar instead of melted butter which I find doesn't give me as great of a result. Definitely mash the bananas into a pace instead of slicing them which gives the bread a bizarre squishy texture. I don't often have sour cream on hand when I have ripe bananas to make this recipe, vanilla yogurt can be subbed with a very similar effect just make sure to scale back on the sugar if the yogurt is indeed sweetened. This recipe can be easily adapted to be baked in muffin tins,: fill muffin cavities almost completely (it won't rise a ton) and bake for about 21 minutes. I would suggest checking with a skewer at the 19 minute mark though. A simple streusel topping made with a small amount of butter, oats, brown sugar, cinnamon, and flour can be mixed up and put on after filling the muffin cavities as a nice variation of taste and texture.

5

I totally agree about this being the most moist and delicious banana bread recipe I've EVER made, hands down! People always tell me what a good cook/baker I am and I have tried a variety of banana bread recipes over  the 50+ yrs. I've been baking, but this is the absolute winner!  I will never use any other!  I believe part of the secret is slicing the bananas instead of mashing as most other recipes call for.  I've made it exactly as written, but for just a tiny bit tastier option I used vanilla yogurt instead of the sour cream.  Plain yogurt I'm sure would be great also.

This was delicious! Followed another reviewer's recommendations and increased flour to 1 3/4 cup, also used 1tsp each  baking powder and baking soda. Mashed the bananas. Will definitely make again. My family loved it, it was nice and moist, appropriately dense. This is my go to recipe now, although next time I may try cutting back on the sugar a little bit, there's so much natural sweetness from the bananas I think I could cut back some on the sugar and not be too big s deal.
**update June 2018- made this with 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/4 cup white sugar and was still plenty sweet. I may cut back to 1/2 cup total next time.

text:
I didn't have any walnuts and quite frankly I don't care for walnuts in general. I feel like they take the sweetness away from the bread so I substituted it with dried banana chips! And my goodness you guys it came out to be heavenly. The chips had softened up with hints of crunch and flavor. Perfect addition. "Double Banana Bread"

This recipe is perfect except, instead of slicing the bananas puree them with a fork before adding to the mixture. 
I put my batter in the fridge for an hour which gave it  amazing texture. Will definitely make again! My boyfriend and dad couldn't get enough of it :)

text:
Delicious & moist! This recipe is a keeper, although I did alter it slightly based on other reviews and my lack of sour cream.
I used 1/2 white and 1/2 brown sugar,  added  1 teaspoon of  baking powder,  used plain Greek yogurt instead of sour cream and mashed my bananas instead of slicing them. 
After greasing the bread pans, I'd suggest that you lightly flour them for an easy release. 
This is a perfect recipe for the brown bananas I keep in my freezer!

text:
I have never posted a review for a recipe but I had to for this one! I just started getting back into baking and decided to make this. It was the best banana/walnut bread I have ever tasted! Since I used two very ripe bananas I only used 1/2 cup of sugar and it was the perfect amount of sweetness. Also, I added the dry and wet ingredients separately and once the wet ingredients were mixed, I slowly added the dry ingredients. I feel it works best that way and won't make any lumps or clumps. Thanks for an amazing recipe!!

Best banana bread recipe! I've used this recipe several times and it never disappoints. text:
Delicious! Very simple, and super-yummy :)

Made a double batch and used 2% Greek Yogurt instead of the sour cream, worked great. Made half the mix into choc-chip muffins (made 16 moderately sized ones) for lunch boxes, and added maybe 2/3 desiccated coconut to the other batch, and a teaspoon coconut essence, and baked as a loaf.

Haven't tried the loaf yet, but texture looks great, and it smells good. The muffins are really good - great texture and taste.

Made a couple of changes cooking - instead of folding,p in the bananas and yogurt, I just kept the mix in my KitchenAid and stirred them in very slowly and just a tiny bit (I was under significant pressure to go play Lego!) I also baked at 375 instead of 350, since my hubby had a wholemeal loaf and meatballs already in the oven!

Great recipe, and adaptable :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making my mom's banana bread recipe for years, which doesn't use sour cream, so I decided to try out this one. I did make some mods suggested by other reviewers, adding 1tsp baking powder and 1tsp lemon juice, and I used three medium mashed bananas (I don't want chunks of banana in my bread!)  I also subbed 1/2 cup whole wheat flour. The batter had a totally different look and texture than I'm used to. The bread rose flat-topped and didn't bake with cracks in the middle like I'm used to. And when the loaf came out of the pan it left the bottom crust stuck to the pan, which I hate!! But the flavor and texture of the bread itself is actually ok, it is really moist if that's what you want. Not as banana-y as my mom's recipe, so personally I still prefer what I grew up on!

Very Simple. Very Easy. Very Delicious.

I've made this a few times now with lots of compliments. I prefer to double the vanilla, skip the nuts, and use mashed instead of sliced bananas, but the original is also good. Even if you're not much of a cook or a baker, try this recipe. It uses simple ingredients and is really easy to make.

I followed this recipe ALMOST exactly. The only thing I did different was to: 1.) Use plain unflavored yogurt instead of sour cream because I was out, and 2. ) Used 4 ripe bananas because that's what I had and didn't want the other 2 bananas to get thrown out. I have never reviewed ANY recipe on here because I didn't have an account.  THIS recipe was so good I came back AND started an account just so I could review it!  I lost all  my recipes in a house fire including the banana bread recipe I used for years.  THIS is going to be my new one.  If you can't decide which one to make, TRY this one!  It's sweet and dark (make sure to use really ripe bananas, that's a secret to GREAT banana bread) and there's NO oil!  I know, I thought it might come out dry, but no.  It's fabulous!  I did a half white sugar and half brown sugar though, because I've always used brown sugar in mine, and I mashed the bananas.  GREAT recipe!  Thank you sooo much for sharing it!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Very moist. Tastes even better when put in the fridge overnight as it becomes denser and more chewy.

I made the following changes (some of it based on what others have said):
1. Butter - at room temperature, not melted
2. Mash the bananas instead of slicing (1 cup)
3. Substituted Greek yoghurt for sour cream to be healthier (same amount).

I also used dark brown sugar instead of white so that it's a little less sweet plus has a smokier taste. But the bread will then turn out darker-looking. I'm wondering how it will taste with honey instead of sugar?

The next time round, I'm going to try and put in chocolate chips in the banana bread! I'm also wondering if this recipe can be varied for pumpkin bread instead...

***
I made it again using white sugar plus the changes above (points 1 - 3). This time round, it turned out lighter, moister, fluffier and way larger! Not sure if it was due to the sugar, the larger eggs that I used, or a different brand of Greek yoghurt, but this time round it tastes even better. It only required 50 minutes to cook on the bottom tray.

I made this as-is and the next time, I will lightly toast the walnuts prior to adding them to the batter. Outstanding bread and thanks for sharing.  :)  **April, 2018 JUST ONE BANANA?  I've made this many times but today, I made muffins, using qty. 8 as a guide (for whole egg, not a fraction and one banana.) Subbed mayo for not available sour cream. Works best with fully mashed banana. Made 8 in muffin paper cups, baked 20 mins. at 350. Slightly less sweet than the original quantity; might add 2 teaspoons more of sugar IF forced to use mayo again instead of sour cream. **Tried it again with the one banana, sour cream. Just like the bread. Nice "mistake" to make in case there's only the one banana left.

text:
I was feeling a little under the weather today and didn't quite feel like baking, but I definitely needed something warm to eat - so I loosely measured the ingredients for this recipe and hoped for the best. I was surprised by how easy it was (for a beginner); I could've made it in one bowl if I so chose - and it was absolutely delicious! Hands down, the moistest banana bread I've ever made. 

I highly recommend adding the walnuts. They really do make a difference. I might try baking it again and substituting some low-fat Greek yogurt for the sour cream, just to keep things on the healthier side.

Happy baking :)

text:
This is the best banana bread I've ever tasted. It's moist but has a slightly crunchy exterior. And it's not too sweet.

I used all of the ingredients listed.

I did mash the bananas rather than slice them and I creamed my butter and sugar before adding the other ingredients. 

All and all, it's a great banana bread base and will make it again.

****I gave my sister a loaf the first time I made it and she and her husband love this bread.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe. I made it almost exactly as stated with just a couple of minor tweaks. Because my husband and I both find a lot of banana bread lacking in banana flavor, I chose to add an additional banana. The 3 bananas provided the perfect amount of banana flavor for us. Instead of slicing the bananas, I went back to kindergarten-like behavior and had some fun with smooshing them. I also very lightly whipped everything with a mixer on the lowest setting in order to get a fluffier resulting banana bread just because that's my preference. Worked like a charm. The bread is moist too. Perfect all around.

By far the best banana bread recipe I've found. Very moist with a great banana flavor.  After making this recipe per the instructions multiple times, I decided to try a few variations, and I find that I prefer to leave out the walnuts and add three bananas instead of two (and mashed, instead of sliced). text:
I have four boys and they ALL love this banana bread! I do mash the bananas, chopping them doesn't blend them into the bread the way I like. This way it's distributes flavor more evenly. I always double the recipe. *A note to those of you who want to make cupcake style, it works great. Depending on your oven usually cook roughly 20 minutes for a batch of 12. Check the Center with a toothpick. I've also added chocolate chips which is a big hit with the boys!

text:
This is the only banana bread recipe I ever make anymore. Out of 10 desserts that were brought in to a Thanksgiving pot luck, this banana bread is disappearing fastest, while others have not even been touched.  It is wonderfully moist with great flavor.

I should note that I make this recipe exactly as written EXCEPT for the bananas.  I mash them instead of slicing because I don't think I'd enjoy chunks of banana in the bread.  I'm not sure how much this changes the recipe since I usually use bananas ripe enough that slicing is not much of an option anyway.

This is the best banana bread I've ever made, well actually this is the first time I've ever made banana bread. It turned out perfect. I followed the advice of several other reviewers by adding a 1/2 cup semisweet chocolate chips and a 1/2 tsp cinnamon. Plus I used three bananas which was equivalent of 1 cup of bananas, and I mashed them to smithereens. The bread is moist and flavorful.  (review #2) I tried adding some baking powder this time as someone else suggested, bad idea. This batch of banana bread was a bit dry.

text:
Delicious! I don't usually substitute, but I didn't have sour cream and I REALLY wanted to try this recipe as soon as I saw it. I did have cream cheese, so I mixed 6 tbsp of cream cheese with 1.5 tbsp of milk in my mini food processor. It worked out great! I made large muffins instead of a loaf because I can portion control a lot easier when they are in muffin form. So, I baked them in my muffin tin for 15 mins and they came out perfect! Next time I will use sour cream and see if it makes a difference, but I don't see how they can get much better than this. Highly recommend this recipe!

Delicious but I substituted chocolate chips for the nuts and mashed the bananas.  I also used yogurt instead of sour cream and creamed room temp butter with sugar  instead of melting the butter. I made it the original way first but preferred the texture and taste this way.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Banana bread is one of those elusive recipes that there is simply so many versions of, its hard to find the "perfect" one. When I made this, I was skeptical, I have made dozens of batches of banana bread just to fall off the wagon,  temporarily give up the search, and give the leftovers to the dog. But this particular recipe is on point! Its moist, not too dense and not at all mushy. Its sweet,  flavorful, with the perfect amount of banana flavor. I absolutely loved it. My stepdaughters, and my 2 year old loved it too! I did follow the recommendation of using 1 3/4 cups of flour, a tsp of baking powder in addition to the baking soda, and I of course mashed the bananas.  I immediately put this in my actual recipe box. Thank you, vjonsson!

text:
Delicious! I did however mash the banana, doubled the vanilla and cut back on the sugar(used 3/4). Will make this again as its a nice change from my personal banana bread recipe, and it's a good way to use up any Sourcream you may have leftover. Next time iI may cut back the sugar even more will try 2/3 cup. Definitely a keeper though!
Update:) I've been enjoying this recipe, and have found that cutting back sugar to 1/2 is amazing. The Bananas already add sweetness. Made these into cupcake sized muffins (15).replacing all the sour cream with Greek yogurt is a healthy alternative, and you get that same tangy flavor and moisture.

text:
I freeze bananas that have gone brown and when I thaw them out, they're usually a molten mess.  No need to slice the bananas as I only have to cut off one end of the peel and the banana slides out.

I made this just as the recipe indicated and it was heavenly.  I think I'll make another one tomorrow just to bring to work.  My in-laws are here and they're both loving this bread.  It's great when I can show mom-in-law what I can do in the kitchen. :)
