text:
My 5 year old grandson devours this bread.  It has to have nuts in it or he will not eat it.  My daughter will not eat with nuts, so I have to divide the batter into 2 loaf pans. They aren't as high as using just one, but delicious just the same.  The only difference is I use 1 cube of butter flavored Crisco, creamed with the sugar,  and get the same yummy results.  I also use 3  bananas, mashed well.  It is definitely a tried and true recipe.

text:
I've made this recipe a few times now, with the exception of mashing and not slicing the bananas, and it consistently produces a bread that lives up to its title. It is quick and easy and you can customize it also by adding chocolate chips or spices (another reviewer suggested cinnamon and cloves which turned out great). It turns out fine with or without the nuts. I have also made it with coconut oil substituted 1:1 for the butter and it came out great as usual. Also works well for muffins! Thanks!

text:
I set the oven as directed and used all the same measurements but I made a few minor alterations to accommodate what I had at hand. 

I had already puréed a cup of banana (1 1/2 bananas) so I used that instead of two sliced bananas. I replaced the sour cream and vanilla extract with vanilla yogurt, and because I didn't have any walnuts laying around I just used white chocolate chips (I usually throw some sliced almonds in what I am making but I was out). I also used demerara instead of white sugar.

Instead of keeping the eggs separate from the other wet ingredients I mixed them all together before throwing them in with the dry ingredients and used a manual egg beater to mix it all together, then a fork to make sure it was completely blended.

It's still warm and over half the loaf is gone already! Thank you, Janet!

text:
Love this recipe- the sour cream really makes it! Slight variations: I creamed room temp butter with the sugar, then added the eggs one at a time, vanilla and finally beat in the dry ingredients. In a separate bowl, I combined the sour cream and bananas using a hand mixer, then stirred it into the larger mixture. Baked in two small loaf pans for about 45 minutes. Freezes beautifully, too.

text:
I thought this banana bread was awesome. I made some changes to fit what I had in the house and for dietary restrictions. 1) I had no sour cream so I added 2-3 more bananas, smashed. All my bananas were smashed. 2) I used gluten free flour instead of normal flour. 3) I used Splenda instead of regular sugar. It still turned out out AWESOME !! Very moist and delicious. I made it a second time using sour cream, Splenda and gluten free flour. Turned out AWESOME as well. I needed to add some water (about 1/2 cup) to all the recipes I made due to the batter being too thick. But other than that, it was great!

I made this earlier this week to rave reviews. I did make a few changes, starting with leaving the nuts out. With so many people having allergies to nuts these days, I erred on the side of caution and left them out. I also opted to mash the bananas, rather than leave them sliced. And, in addition to the vanilla, I added a couple of teaspoons of banana flavoring. The resulting bread was very tasty, soft textured, and had an intense banana flavor. I'll be making this again this week.

text:
Super Moist!

We also sometimes make it with these adjustments for sweeter, moist banana bread:
-1/4 cup semi-sweet mini chocolate chips
-Replace 1 Cup Sugar, with 1/2 Cup Brown Sugar, 1/2 Cup White Sugar
-Coconut oil instead of butter
-Bake at 325 for 90 minutes

text:
Love this! I've always hated the taste of synthetic banana, so it was great to find such an easy recipe. The only thing I didn't like was the pieces of banana in the bread, the banana taste would have been weaker, plus biting into a piece of browned banana wouldn't be pleasant, so I pureed them instead. I also cut down the sugar by half. I usually wait until I have very ripe bananas to make the bread. It gives it more flavor plus it helps sweeten it. Overall, very great and very tasty. If I could give it five more stars I would!

text:
I made this bread last night for the kids (because a bunch of bananas went bad overnight) and it is excellent. I only tried a small piece but I wanted so much more. I did mash the bananas like many reviewers said, and my bananas were mushy ripe. I made a double batch so I could give some away, and had to make just one change based on what I had available. I used 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup Brown. Also my husband and I couldn't decide if our bananas were medium or small so I used all 6 bananas and the banana flavor was perfect. The only real change I made was adding a teaspoon of cinnamon. After about 45 minutes in the oven the kitchen smelled delicious. I did cook for 60 minutes at 350 in a gas oven and that worked out well. I will definitely use this recipe again because these would make perfect small gifts for co-workers at Christmas time.

text:
Far and away the best banana bread. Easy to mix up, no mixer needed. I bake for 65 min. I add a dash of cinnamon and I mash bananas, that's all I change. This is so delicious and moist. The butter adds so much flavor too.  Decadent treat but I always end up sharing it with many people. I bake in a glass 8x8" pan for 40 min.

text:
Best banana bread recipe I've ever had, hands down. I love that I don't need rotten black bananas for this recipe - because they are sliced I can use just slightly over-ripe ones.  I've substituted yogurt for the sour cream sometimes and it's just as good.  I've also tried chocolate chunks instead of nuts last time and it was also fantastic.  
This is the only banana bread I will ever make again!

text:
Love this! It's a little too sweet for my taste so I cut the sugar way down to 1/3 cup. Super ripe bananas sweetens it perfectly. I substituted half of the butter with coconut oil. I added chocolate chips because you can never go wrong with chocolate + banana. Fun to make with my 5 year-old, I just prep the dry stuff ahead of time and let her handle the banana mashing. I doubled the batch to bring some to my sister-in-law who just had twins but after one bite I decided I didn't want to share and will just buy her something else. It's that delicious!

text:
Best recipe I've found.  It's now my go to.  Made exactly as described but added a pinch  of cinnamon and did 2 large Bananas  instead of medium. And if you do that u will need to keep an eye in it and make sure it doesn't over flow.  I just tuck it in all around.  then instead of slicing   I just smashed them in the peel until they  squeezed out.  It's important to fold the sour cream and Bananas  .  I also rotate half way through and do not take it out of pan when done .  I use pam for greasing..

text:
Like everyone else said- MASH THE BANANAS!!! Other than that, this worked out great. I used to make banana bread with yogurt instead of sour cream, but I didn't really taste the difference. For extra points, wait til the bananas get brown before trying this, and bake with a shallow pan of water in the oven, preferably on the rack directly below. I brought this to my class and everyone loved it- maybe the professor will give me extra points on the final exam?

text:
I altered the recipe after reading the tips of several reviewers. Alterations: Used 3 bananas instead of 2, added 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp nutmeg, used 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 white as opposed to all white, added 2 handfuls of coconut flakes and several strawberries(both my idea). Used shortening instead of butter as I did not have much butter. Omitted walnuts. It turned out very good, but I still feel improvement could be made. Next time I make this I will try toasting the coconut for more flavor, and using butter or at least butter flavored shortening as well as including the walnuts. Also, it took 5-10 min longer to bake for me.

text:
This is a magnificent recipe. I've made it about 6 times now, as written and tweaked. This is what I ended up with. I mash the bananas. I added the sour cream and vanilla to the butter mixture BEFORE I combined it with the dry ingredients. I also added one tsp of banana extract and 1/4 tsp of butter extract. Extracts can make the things your baking come out over-the-top fantastic. But ease into it. It's easy to use to much.

text:
I recently tried this recipe and loved it! I did not follow it exactly. The only thing I did different was use self-rising flour and omitted the baking soda & salt. Also, I had only Pecans on hand and used them.

I was so pleasantly surprised at how moist and delicious it turned out! I love it. I have shared it with family & they loved it. I even had to come back and find the exact recipe to send to my sister.

It tastes more like cake than bread to me. If you need a quick dessert that people will rave about, try this! Thank you so much for sharing your recipe, Janet!

I found that in order to get 1 cup of mashed bananas it took about 3 medium bananas. I used the mini chopper for the walnuts. I made this with these variations from naples34102 and it was delicious! "I cream the softened butter with the sugar (not melted). I add 1 tsp. lemon juice with the vanilla, and use 1 tsp. each of baking soda and baking powder, and 1-3/4 c. flour. Finally, regardless of how many bananas are used it should equal 1 cup." I smashed/creamed the bananas, though. This will be my go to banana bread recipe from now on!

userID:

Display Name:
Robin Stark
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5683033.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually make Banana bread using a recipe I got from my ex-sister-in-law years ago.  I modified that recipe to get it to the flavor and consistency I liked and so I thought I would try this recipe because of the ratings it got and see how it turned out.  I doubled the recipe as I wanted two loaves.  I did substitute half of the sugar with brown sugar and added cinnamon, nutmeg and a dash of clove. I also used half of the baking soda and then used baking powder for the other half. I used some plain Greek yogurt for part of the sour cream as I needed to use up the yogurt.  It turned out beautifully and came out of pan very nicely.  It was a little darker than I like but was completely done on the inside - knife came out clean. I might add one more banana in the future and maybe shorten the baking time to get a lighter crust but I do like the chunks of banana in the bread.  I did not slice the bananas but mashed them into small chunks and that was a nice change.  I did omit the walnuts as I am allergic but I would try pecans in the future.  My daughter said that she thought this bread was more "fluffy" than my usual. Thank you for this great recipe.  My family loved it!

text:
I made this banana bread twice in 2 weeks. First time I had wayy to much banana, and it came out flat and solid, but good. Second time around, I followed recipe using organic ingredients but substituted nuts for instant Quaker oats (1cup+). it turned out perfectly and filling! Great recipe for sure!!!

I did not mash the bananas. Rather, I combined the sour cream with the bananas inside a blender, and blended them together.
Afterwards, I poured on to flour mixture and stirred. While stirring, I added the 1+cups of Quaker oats.

text:
After reading some of the reviews I did make a few adjustments.  I  added 1/2 C brown sugar and reduced white sugar to 1/2 C. I added 1 tsp of lemon juice, 1 tsp of baking powder, 1/4 C flour, and omitted the salt. I mashed the bananas measuring 1 C, took about 2 1/2 medium bananas.  since I did not have any walnuts I added pecans instead.  This bread came out moist and flavor was amazing.  It sliced up perfectly. My husband said it was best banana bread he ever tasted. Did not take long for this one to disappear. This one is a keeper....kdp1023

text:
I'd never made banana bread before, but I had some really ripe bananas and I wanted to try since I really love banana bread. This recipe was really easy to follow. I did follow other reviewers though and mashed my bananas instead of slicing them. I skipped the walnuts because I didn't have any. I'd also never heard of using sour cream in bread before. Well, the result was amazing! My banana bread was moist and tastes great! It was a huge hit!

They came out amazing!! Just the right amount of sweetness and so moist yummmmm.  Never made banana nut bread before and I'm not a baker at all but these were so good... I just took this out of the oven and it looks and smells delicous!  I doubled the recipe and used 2 bunt pans.  It baked in 50 minutes.
I greased and floured the pans and the loaves didn't stick.  Baked at 325'.  New oven...350 tested ar 380.  I baked 6 very ripe bananas like cakin and bakin suggested. city:

country:
None
text:
I've been using this recipe for several years and think everyone mashing their bananas is really missing the boat. The hot sweet pockets of molten banana when it's fresh out the oven are sensational but once it cools, the chunks of banana just make this banana bread out of this world sensational. I follow the recipe nearly exactly, except I rarely have nuts on hand due to cost, but do have overripe bananas to save from wasting often, so I generally do not use them. I think it would be better with them however. Otherwise, I am slightly more uptight about measurement so I measure 1 and a half cups banana chunks per loaf. This gives me a loaf that is incredibly decadent.  #BANANACHUNKSRULE

text:
I've made this twice in one week and it's a no fail recipe. It's also very flexible. I use self rising flour (don't add baking powder or salt), half a cup of sugar with 12 sweet n low packets, 3 mashed bananas and chopped white chocolate chunks on top. It's VERY moist and delicious! Everyone's oven temps are different so check your bread at 50 minutes because my edges burn at 60 minutes.

region:

country:

text:
vjonsson is right! The moistest banana bread ever. Moist, sweet, delicious & golden crispy edges. Sooo good. My 10 yr. old son would've eaten the whole loaf if I hadn't stopped him.
My only changes: used my homemade plain yogurt in place of sour cream, (healthier & all I had on hand) used 1 tsp. baking powder in addition to b. soda, mashed the bananas rather than sliced. (per suggestion of other reviewers)
I didn't have any walnuts so made it without. I've made a lot of banana bread over the yrs. & this was the best. It's lighter, not quite as heavy as a lot of loafs. (maybe the b. powder helped w/that) It will be my go-to recipe from now on. YUM (:

text:
I just made this for the first time & it is delicious!!  Added about 3/4 tsp cinnamon, dash of nutmeg, and dash of pumpkin pie spice.  Otherwise followed recipe exactly as written.  Will definitely be making again.  Would make great gifts, in fact I'm taking some to my boyfriend's parents tonight.

UPDATE:  I’ve made this this quite a few times since with the spices above and it’s always been delicious. The last few times I’ve made it at altitude (Denver, 5280 ft elevation), the only change I needed to make with shortening the baking time to about 50 minutes.  Last night I tried substituting the bananas with 3/4 of a cup canned pumpkin, continued to use the spaces above, but I didn’t have any nuts this time. It still turned out fantastic! This is such a great recipe!

text:
I love this recipe! I only made a couple of adjustments. I creamed the butter and sugar together rather than using melted butter. I also puréed the bananas instead of slicing (1cup). I also used half sour cream and half cream cheese, but only bc I didn't have enough sour cream. I left out the walnuts bc my hubby doesn't like them (booooo), but it still turned out amazing and will do it this way again! I doubled the recipe and made 4 mini loaves and 20 mini muffins. The mini muffins cooked for 20 mins and the loaves for 50 mins.

text:
Tried this recipe and thought it came out pretty darn good, though I have to admit that I've never baked banana bread before. I also didn't stick to the recipe exactly. I didn't have sour cream, so substituted Greek yogurt (all I had was strawberry), changed out 1/2 the amount of white sugar with brown sugar and added a pinch of cinnamon. Smelled awesome while baking and came out moist and yummy! I used a 10 x 10" glass dish and it was done in ~45 min. As some of the other reviews have indicated, next time I'd probably opt to mash at least some of the bananas and perhaps cube up the rest (vs. slice).

text:
GLUTEN FREE: Made double recipe
3cups - substitute gluten free flour
shy 2cups - substitute organic cane sugar for granulated
1/4 cup - rice or coconut milk
removed vanilla extract
remove sour cream, replace with applesauce
replaced walnuts with almonds
- mixed all dry ingredients & almonds
- mixed eggs & melted butter (3 organic eggs, 1 cup organic butter)
--whisked in dry ingredients
--added applesauce (1 cup)
--added bananas (4 sliced into rounds)
baked on 350 in 2 greased bread pans
65 - 75 minutes -- depends on how high you filled your pans

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3670969.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe for banana bread. It turns out moist and sweet, as good as loaves in any bakery or diner. The first two times I made the recipe as a loaf, and the last time I made it into muffins. The changes I made were using two less tablespoons of butter; for flour, used one cup whole wheat and half cup white; for sugar, used half cup brown and half cup white; and for sour cream, I chose low fat. With these substitutions to make the mix a bit healthier, none of the sweetness was lost. As a loaf, it's dense and delicious, and as muffins, they are lighter to bite into, and equally as delicious. This is a household favorite!

text:
I am not a banana bread fan at all, but we had some over ripe bananas to put to use. First time I made these, I followed the recipe and was pretty pleased, considering how much I don't like banana bread. The second time, I tweaked it and I just may be a banana bread girl, after all. This round, I added 1 teaspoon of cinnamon and 1 cup of chocolate chips. Also, I swapped half of the white sugar for brown sugar. I used a muffin pan and baked for 22-25 minutes.
Review:
Rating:
5

2014-08-31T19:54:44.913

country:
None
text:
This is my favorite banana bread recipe to make.  It is so easy, and is nearly perfect everytime.  I would say perfect except when following the recipe as is, the extreme moist bread tends to fall apart in your hands, making it a very delicious but messy treat.  I have modified it to use wheat flour, and find that just that simple adjustment has created the perfect banana bread.  Other modifications that I have made (depending on my mood), I have made it without nuts, with chocolate chips, and also mini loaves.  Everytime it comes out great!  Love it!  Thanks for sharing!

I made this following the recipe exactly as written the first time, just so I would know how it's supposed to turn out. It was so good! After reading the reviews, I also made it a few other ways with different things changed. They were all good! This recipe apparently can't be messed up. I did eventually decide I should health it up a little if I want to eat banana bread everyday, so I made a completely overhauled version using this as a base recipe. Even that version turned out good even though there's no sugar in it and I used ground oatmeal as flour. But nothing quite beats the original on a splurge day :)

text:
Great banana bread recipe...  I did find a cool substitution if you find out (too late) that you're out of eggs.  I substituted 150 grams of a good Greek yogurt (Oikos, vanilla) for the two eggs and made the recipe like normal.  Brilliant!!!  I'm almost tempted to try different, complementary, flavors.  I also use VERY ripe (essentially black and starting to smell fermented) and cream them together with the sugar before adding the rest of the ingredients.

text:
Ok, I made just about every substitution imaginable, to have fun w/ it and to make it healthier (and gluten-free).  I replaced the butter w/ organic coconut oil (yum), rice-flour w/ some flax seeds for the regular flour, chopped almonds instead of walnuts, and half plain organic yogurt (I didn't have enough sour cream).  I always use super ripe (the blacker the better) bananas and mash them.  I used 3.  It turned out amazing and guilt-free!  Give it a try...

I made this for the last big family picnic and made a double batch. The first batch I made exactly as the recipe called for, the only difference being that I mashed the bananas before using them as other reviewers had suggested, and also added a tablespoon of lemon extract for more flavor. The second one I sort of came up with on my own for additives. I wanted something more heavy and spicy so I had some leftover blueberries and I added 1 cup of them to the mix. I also added 1tsp of nutmeg, 1/2 tsp of allspice, and 1 tablespoon cinnamon. The crowd loved it, and both were eaten quickly! It was split down the middle as to which one was best. I was very pleased. Just wish I would have gotten to eat a little more for myself!

text:
This was great! I did tweak it a bit, but the texture on this is what's so good about it, and I'm sure it is that way without my tweaks.  I used whole wheat flour (1 3/4 cups) so I used 3 bananas to compensate for this.  I added 1 tsp. cinnamon, and used plain yogurt instead of sour cream because it's what I had on hand. I also used half brown sugar, half regular sugar (it just sounded like a good idea!).  I took the advice of others and put in 1 tsp each of baking soda and baking powder.  I put in chocolate chips in place of nuts because I can't make banana bread without chocolate chips :)  Baked for 1 hour and 15 minutes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good recipe. It was a lot lighter than my usual dense banana bread recipe. Save mashing my bananas and splitting the sugar half white, half light brown, I didn't make too many changes. I initially tried to "cream" the butter and sugar like others suggested, but it wasn't coming together very well, so I had to semi-melt my butter and sugar post hoc--opened the oven door and sat the bowl on the door to gradually warm the butter/sugar. It was still creamy but with a little melt. It did get nice and fluffy after that. This did take a at least an hour in my oven (loaf pan), but the bananas seemed undercooked, if that's possible. Maybe that's due to my oven and bananas. But all in all, this was pretty good.

text:
It was nice and moist. I also mashed the bananas instead of slicing.
Instead of walnuts, I added 2 spoonfuls of peanut butter.
Instead of the butter, I added about 1/3 cup of vegetable oil (given that the peanut butter is oily already)
I reduced sugar to about 1/2 cup. 
I baked it for about 50 min and then turned the oven off and let it sit for another 10 min inside the oven (I was afraid of drying it out).
It came out well!

text:
I've made this bread several times now.  Its a good recipe by itself.  The bread was very moist but nothing spectacular.   After making it exactly by the recipe, I decided to try variations and I have found mashing 3 bananas  gives it a much fuller banana flavor.  I have substituted plain and banana flavored yogurt for the sour cream.  Both worked nicely.  My favorite bread is when I mashed 3 bananas, used banana flavored yogurt and added cinnamon.  Very tasty.

text:
I found this a bit fluffier than many banana bread recipes, and therefore a lot better- perfect! I use my KitchenAid for al the stirring and folding, and maybe that's why it is lighter. I made it the original way, and then tried with with half butter and half unsweetened coconut yogurt- even better! Slicing the bananas preserves more of the flavor. I often slice them, freeze them and then thaw tem briefly before tossing them in- still perfect. We love this bread  with 1/2 cup mini chocolate chips folded in.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this banana nut bread and it's delicious. Sour cream is the reason this comes out so moist. I think you could add sour cream to any banana nut bread recipe and it would improve the flavor and be moist. The few tweaks I made to the recipe is that I used one stick of butter, not two, used pecans instead of walnuts and mashed two bananas before adding them to the mix. I meant to add a touch of cinnamon and clove like others suggested but forgot...didn't matter as the flavor is great without added spices. Poured mix into one 9x5 pan, baked as recommended; put foil over top at about half way into cooking time.  Perfection, truly.

text:
Moist, easy to make, great flavor, and even better next day when wrapped up tightly to let flavors blend; it also toasts well.  Only things I did differently were to mash 2/3 of the bananas and cut the other 1/3 of total into pieces and I used a sugar/cinnamon coating in pans after greasing. I used one regular loaf pan and one small loaf pan so I could freeze one for later. The worse (riper) my bananas look, the better it tastes. This is a really great recipe for the amount of work! Thank you

None
text:
This basic recipe is awesome! I used the suggested changes to increase the flour to 1 3/4 cups and one tsp each of baking soda and baking powder. Also mashed the bananas (mine took 2 large bananas). I subbed pecans for the walnuts - just a personal preference for my family. Just for anyone else trying to stretch it for 2 - I split the recipe into 2 smaller loaf pans (the grocery store disposable appx 8 1/2 x 3 inch) so that I could take one loaf to a friend. I cooked them at 325 for 55 minutes and they came out perfectly. Thanks for a wonderful new recipe for my binder!

country:
None
text:
Very yummy banana bread. I doubled the recipe but used 3 1/2 white/whole wheat flour, 2 cups of mashed banana, 1 cup of brown sugar and 1/2 cup of white (instead of the full 2 cups doubling would call for). IMO, it tastes so much better with less sugar; the flavor of the bread really comes through instead of mainly sugar. Did not add nuts. Also added 1 tsp. baking powder along with the soda. I saw where someone had creamed the butter and sugar, but I'm a lazy baker so I just followed the recipe melting the butter, and it turned out great. So moist and delicious!

This was my 1st time making banana bread & it was really good with a few minor variations. First, I used room temperature butter rather than melting it. text:
I have made this before per he recipe and it was wonderful. Today, I didn't have all of the ingredients and changed a few things and I am now in love! I tripled the recipe to make three loaves this morning. I ended up not having three cups of sugar, so I used 2 cups white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar. We also had no nuts, so those we not used. After creaming sugar and ROOM TEMP butter together, we beat in the bananas. And the final alteration was beating in the sour cream last instead of folding it in. I am used to dense, moist banana bread, but this one actually turned out fluffy and moist.

text:
This is the best banana bread that I have ever made, and I have tried a lot of them!  Made recipe as written with two small changes: one is that I mashed the bananas and the second is that I added about 1/2 tsp cinnamon.  Made this into muffins and baked at 350 for about 18 minutes.  I also make a glaze to add to the top off all my banana bread recipes - 1 part water and 1 part sugar mixed together and dribbled on top before baking.  (Which I guess would be a third adaptation.)  Delicious!

text:
Yes, this really is the best banana bread recipe going. Like others, I agree that the bananas should be coarsely mashed - and all bananas are not created equal - so I go with 1 1/2 cups of mashed to get a good banana flavor. Never have sour cream around, so I add yogurt instead of the sour cream. Mix in frozen cranberries or blueberries for a little tang. I always seem to have more volume than will fit in a loaf pan, so I use a bundt to avoid spillovers. It's a never fail recipe!

text:
I was making a different banana bread recipe for YEARS and just thought I'd try something different.  THIS is my new go-to for banana bread! So so sooo good. Followed it pretty close but I didn't melt the butter, just softened it and used the mixer for that and the sugar, otherwise mixed everything else by hand. I also mashed the bananas and this worked out fabulous. Everyone is raving its so moist! Yummy!!!!

text:
This is a good recipe but I adjusted it to what I had available. I didn't have sour cream so I soured half cup milk with half tablespoon vinegar. I used quarter cup butter and quarter cup applesauce. I halved the sugar and added quarter cup dark chocolate chips. I used 1 cup flour and half cup ground walnuts and added a tablespoon of chia seeds. It turned out very moist and delicious!

text:
This recipe is a keeper. This bread had a beautiful dark brown color on the outside. Even though it had great banana flavor and was very moist, it wasn't super dense or heavy. I will be adding this to my recipe collection. I used 1 cup mashed banana and added a little cinnamon to my batter, as well as adding a teaspoon of lemon juice with the vanilla, as someone else suggested. I had several compliments, including one very picky eater who usually won't eat banana bread with nuts but he loved this. Fantastic!

Going of script, but I was SO pleased with the results.

Just made this and it came out beautiful and super yummy! my husband who is not a fan of banana bread loved it and had seconds:) I used plain Greek yogurt in lieu of sour cream, cous it's what I had. No walnuts, but did sprinkle halved almonds on top more for decoration than anything. I used 3/4 cup of brown sugar. came out moist and perfect sweet wise. Oh and inspired by one of the reviews, i too creamed the butter and sugar with a wooden spoon, rather than a mixer. Will be making this often, thanks so much for such a good recipe!

text:
I followed the adjustments given by naples34102 and the results were amazing! I made twice the recipe on 2 slightly-smaller loaf pans (8 inches), filled it 7/8 full and baked the bread for 55 minutes. I had leftover batter and made a dozen cupcakes at 325 degrees F for 25 minutes and they turned out great as well! The loaves and cupcakes were moist and light with just the right amount of sweetness. I will definitely make this again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2681443.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this with a few of the previously suggested variations and it came out incredibly. I used 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/2 cup white, added 1 tsp nutmeg and a 1 tsp cinnamon. I also did as naples34102 suggested and did 1 tsp of each baking soda and powder. I used a total of three bananas which was more equal to a cup and is the amount many other reviews said you should use (and I needed to get rid of some ripe bananas!). I unfortunately did not have any sour cream or yogurt, so I had to do without but it was still moist and delicious. I substituted the walnuts with crushed pumpkin spice almonds, which planters brings out around the holidays. Finally, I used a metal cupcake tin and baked for about 20 min at 325.

text:
Incredible recipe!!  I had a bunch of frozen bananas to use and I took a chance that this recipe would work. *Note frozen bananas are very slimy to peel but the texture was perfect for mashing. Be sure to drain any defrost moisture first.*

I ran out of sour cream so I used Greek yogurt instead. Took advice from one of the reviews and added a bit of allspice and baked at 325 degrees for 1 hour and 10 min.  Bread came out moist but firm. Perfect for slicing and nowhere near heavy or brick-like. Took it to a party and the guests LOVED it! My new go-to!!!

I've been using a pretty good banana bread recipe since I was a teenager. It had been awhile since I had made it and I didn't feel like looking for the recipe. This one was very similar so I picked it. Yum! This one is so much better than my old recipe! The texture was wonderful! The butter doesn't need to be melted, just softened. I also added about 1/3 cup brown sugar. (My old recipe used 1 1/2 cups sugar). It wasn't too sweet, just right! Mash the bananas with a fork.

text:
I used Napes34102's modifications and substituted Greek yogurt for sour cream. Also, I didn't have any eggs for I made two "flax seed eggs" which meant before everything else, I mixed together 2 tablespoons ground flax seed and 6 tablespoons of water and left them until they became gelatinous, stirring every now and then. Then when it came time for the eggs I just poured that in. This recipe worked great, even with the vegan adjustment!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I needed to recycle some raisins and almonds left over from making homemade glug and I thought banana bread would be good so I picked this recipe. WONDERFUL. The only changes I made were adding dashes of cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves to incorporate the flavors of the glug infused raisins and almonds a bit throughout the dough, and I used 3 mashed bananas instead of 2 sliced. The result was a very rich, very moist bread that melted in the mouth and filled the house with a divine aroma as it baked. Best of all, as the bread took over an hour to get done, most of the alcohol content from the raisins and almonds got baked out, so the result wasn't the least bit boozy.

text:
This is some amazingly good banana bread.  I have made this exactly as written and also with some changes, and got equally good results.  Here are the changes I made:  I subbed an equal amount of coconut oil in place of the butter (firm, refrigerate if liquid).  I also subbed plain nonfat yogurt for the sour cream.  I prefer the bananas mashed.

text:
I think this is a good base recipe that with a few modifications comes out great!  I change the amount of bananas to 3 large ripe bananas coarsely mashed.  Also brown sugar instead of white really adds a nice touch.  I add a little nutmeg, cinnamon, and allspice to the batter and then sprinkle them on top before putting it in the oven.  Finally nuts are optional, it comes out just as good without them!  Over all so yummy!

I made 12 muffins out of this recipe; I only had to bake them for about twenty minutes! They are great in moisture and flavor. Like most people, I didn't have any sour cream on hand, so I used about 1/3 cup of mayonnaise instead. I also used 3 bananas instead of 2, just because I had them. text:
I'm giving three stars because I too made quite a few changes to get it taste 'rich': I mashed the bananas, added half teaspoon of cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon of ginger (adding ginger was an accident actually), I used yogurt instead of sour cream, used a little baking powder as well as baking soda, and added 5-10grams less butter than the amount it says in the recipe. It might differ from oven to oven, but 60 minutes of baking time was about 10 minutes too much for me -- make sure you keep an eye in the oven. Me, my friend, and my mother agree that the result was delicious. Next time I won't add ginger because I'm not a fan of spice, but if you like spicy, you can try a tiny bit ginger like I accidentally did.

text:
Great recipe...bread comes out moist with a tender crumb, not heavy and dense like most banana breads.  I followed the suggestions of some other reviewers and mashed the bananas, adding them to the butter/sugar/egg mixture before adding the flour.  I didn't have any sour cream so I used fat free Greek yogurt instead.  At the last minute I decided to add a teaspoon of cinnamon to the batter...glad I did!  I'm generally not a big banana bread fan but I'll be keeping this recipe on hand for those times when I have over ripe bananas to use.

text:
I had a few bananas that were going bad so I thought - why not try and make a banana bread. I made several tweaks to this recipe to suit my tastes - I used 3 bananas instead of 2 because that's just what I had, I also added 1/4th cup of brown sugar and a teaspoon of cinnamon to the recipe. I used enriched bread flour and I didn't have sour cream so I just omitted it and it turned out moist without it. I'm definitely going to try this recipe again but I'm going to play with the amount of sugar it calls for - perhaps do 1/2 cup sugar and 1/4th cup brown just to see. I think that this is a fantastic recipe because it serves as a great template for the bread. Thanks!

text:
I really did enjoy this recipe - but like others have suggested I did make a few changes and it worked out very well. I also creamed my butter with half a cup of white sugar and half a cup with brown sugar, added one teaspoon of cinnamon and half a teaspoon of nutmeg. I did mash the bananas primarily because I don't think my kids would eat it if there were slices and lastly I used the batter and made little muffins instead, easier for little hands to hold. The muffins cooked for 17 min in a 350 oven and they came out perfectly golden brown. Definitely a keeper.

text:
Really good, super moist and over all a great taste. I only had one egg, so I substituted the other egg with a little water and conola oil, and I substituted the sour cream with canola oil and milk. It didnt slice very well, and broke easily but maybe thats my fault for not using all the right ingredients. I chose this recipe because it was the only one I found that only required two bananas, which is all I had. I think it would have been even better if you bump up the bananas to three or four. I think its better if the bananas were mashed because I found a few big chunks in the bread, not that it was a big deal.

text:
Wonderful. I used lady finger banana's from our trees and mashed them up a little over a cup and went light on the sugar like a little more than 3/4 cup. No nuts as the kids hate nuts! This is a great recipe and it can be easily tweeked for all sorts of different variations. Forgot to add I made this into muffins and spray the cupcake liners with canola spray at 30 mins and 350 degrees. I also had more than 12 so i just put the rest into my mini cupcake tin at 20 mins 350 (also sprayed them with canola oil first) and those are good to put in a lunch box side dish for easy eating.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved the taste/texture.  2 loaves evaporated in the office within 2 hours.  On a side note, greek yogurt worked well as a substitution since I was out of sour cream.  Try using 1/2 cup of dark chocolate chips or pecans instead of the 1/2 cup walnuts.  I might go crazy and add more nuts since it seemed less nutty or chocolaty than I would have preferred.  BTW at the office the one with Chocolate chips went fastest.  Also as other people have said the bread should have mashed instead of sliced banana...the riper the more flavor.  1 cup is perfect so if you like to mash the bananas and freeze them like I do just measure out 1 cup portions for when you are in the mood for some fresh banana bread.  It is delish right out of the oven.  I had 6 bananas that worked out to 2 1/2 cups so best to mash and measure if you want consistent results.

text:
I've made this recipe several times now, and it is always delicious and sweet, without being "too sweet." I wasn't crazy about the mushy, purply banana pieces that you get a day or so after baking this bread--so, I started chopping the bananas into smaller pieces, and it's been wonderful every time. I usually bake for only 57-58 minutes, at just a notch under 350 degrees. (My oven runs a little hot)

text:
Great recipe!  Very moist.  I tweaked it by substituting 1/2 the flour for whole wheat flour, and used 3/4 cup demarra sugar instead of white sugar.  It took a little longer to beat it well enough so the sugar was properly blended.   I didn't have sour cream and used nonfat, plain Greek yogurt.  I used three very soft bananas mashed and  also added some semisweet chocolate chips.  I will use this recipe again for certain.

text:
I tried this recipe for the first time today and ended up making two batches. I followed the recipe exactly first batch (and it turned out great), but the second batch I made a few adjustments. I first excluded the walnuts (so my grandmother could eat it) and added only a quarter cup of sour cream. Instead, I added another half banana, and I felt it gave me the same moisture as the first loaf. It also added more banana-flavor to it and reduced the calories by a bit. Overall, a fantastic recipe that left both moist and rich taste with a strong banana foundation. I served it with a scoop of vanilla bean ice cream and my guests loved it.

text:
Best recipe I've found for banana bread and I've tried quite a few. Followed reviewers suggestions to mash the bananas, and added 1 teaspoon of cinnamon. Some reviewers warned of using a mixer with this but I never have a problem. In fact, I use the mixer to work the butter and sugar into a creamy consistency. Someone said it adds too much air, but that's not my experience at all whenever I make breads of any kind. Three bananas instead of two and this was a hit. I'm making my fourth loaf today because I bought a lot of extra bananas and plan on giving a few loaves for family birthdays. This also freezes quite well!

text:
Great! Made a couple small changes and loved it. Used all whole wheat flour, about 6 T of butter (will play around with applesauce next time as some people have mentioned), only 1/2 cup sugar, light sour cream and added in some dark chocolate chips. Mixed as directed and poured into the sprayed pan and then sprinkled a fair amount cinnamon and nutmeg on top to cover. Baked as directed, 350 for 60 minutes and it was perfectly done. I use a full size loaf pan from Pampered Chef and it cooked great.  Will use this recipe again!

text:
Best banana bread I've ever had.  Made several times and will not make another way again.  I have altered this one to add mini chocolate chips, mini Reese cups, and Nutella swirl.  All were fantastic.  If you do use chocolate chips, I prefer the minis so they don't sink to the bottom of the loaf.  Also, if you use the Reese, I suggest chopping them and not using whole for the same reason. Like other reviewers, I also mashed the bananas.

text:
I loved this recipe and so did my kids, and husband. My spouse was amazed when I said that I made it - he was sure I had bought it. I made the recommended changes re: butter, bananas, cinnamon, and nutmeg - and added a pinch of ground cardamom, and loosely covered top with foil halfway through to prevent a burnt top. I think I added too many bananas - probably closer to 1 cup and 1/2, as the mixture overflowed while baking. I also seemed to have the temp too low (at 325) and ended up baking it for 1 hour and 45 mins! It was perfect! I'll try baking at 350 and putting on lower rack next time. Thank you vjonsson for sharing this recipe with us!

This banana bread is the bomb-diggity.

I made a couple of adjustments:
* Used plain non-fat greek yogurt instead of sour cream (NO difference to taste or texture, just less calories and higher protein).
* Smashed the bananas and incorporated them until they were unified completely with the rest of the batter.
* Made muffins instead of loaf, cooked for around 25 minutes.

userID:
9620293
Display Name:
Kasia
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
15
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The trick is to use super ripe bananas and to make thin slices. That way you don't get the weird purple-ish chunks if the banana slices are too large/intact. I save some of the slices to sprinkle on top of the loaf for better distribution too.

I usually cream the butter and sugar instead of using melted butter--just because I'm used to it that way for other recipes. I have done it with melted butter and it made no dramatic difference. 

Otherwise I followed everything the same. I normally check the loaf after 40 minutes of baking to see how it's doing, but I've found that 60 minutes is good for my oven.
Review:

5

text:
DELICIOUS! Totally agree with other reviewers. I had to double this recipe because I knew that based on the reviews, it would be wonderful.  However, I did not have sour cream so I substituted 1 cup evaporated milk with 1 tablespoon white vinegar (for 2 loaves).  I also took another reviewer's suggestion to add another 1/4 cup of flour (1/2 cup for two loaves) but I only added a total of 1 tsp baking soda and 1 tsp baking powder to make my two loaves. I used 4 nice sized bananas, but could have easily added another one.  Overall, this is a GREAT recipe and I will be making it again.  So HAPPY I doubled the recipe! Thank you for a great recipe!

text:
Loved it. I made mini loafs and they were very moist. Used a cup of bananas instead of 2. Measurements is important when cooking. Two could mean so many different volumes. Mom thought I was weird adding sour cream but it worked. I also melted the butter against other suggestions and it made the process easier. I mashed the bananas instead of slicing. Added the baking soda and salt to the butter then the flour so I didn't have to do separate mixing bowls. I split the batter in half and added chocolate chips. I was making this for breakfast the next day and they didn't make it past dinner.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I finally found a banana bread recipe that came out moist! I wasn't fond of the idea of slicing bananas into the bread so I mashed them up. I also ended up using 4 bananas since my bananas were on the smaller scale. I omitted the walnuts because I don't like nuts and used half a cup of whole wheat flour instead since I was out of all purpose. The cooking time took a tad longer than 60 minutes and the top was browning a bit too much so I just covered it with tin foil and lowered the temperature to 325 for another 15 minutes. I brushed a simple sugar syrup onto the cake once it came out of the oven. I'll be coming back to this recipe for when my banana bread cravings kick in!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is definitely one of the top banana breads I have had.  I made it exactly as written except I didn't have walnuts I had pecans so I used them instead.  This has an excellent banana flavor with no spices (like cinnamon or nutmeg) that sometimes make banana bread taste more like a spice cake.  It is very tender, it does cut well and you can easily spread room temperature butter on it but a slice won't stand up to any "manhandling".  I suspect this is due to the sour cream.  But I really like it that way.  This is going to be my new "go to" recipe when I want banana bread.  The only change I plan to make is to increase the walnuts (or pecans depending on what I have on hand) the next time, as I like lots of nuts in banana bread.

text:
My mom and I have been using a different recipe for ages, but when I found this recipe yesterday, I made it right there and then (since the ingredients were convienently already in my pantry). Turns out... My family of 5 finished it off before the day ended! Definitely our new favorite recipe. 

So yeah, most of the ingredients I had, but we didn't have sour cream; too lazy to think of a subsitute, I just decided not to include it. I also took out the nuts because my siblings were allergic. And lastly, thankfully looking at the other reviews beforehand, I mashed the bananas instead of slicing it - thank God I did, there were a few little chunks that I found while eating it and totally saw how slicing would NOT have worked out. So thanks for those reviews! 

After all that, it turned out 100% amazing, like I said, we loved it!

userID:

Display Name:
duddie18
isPro:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is best banana bread I have ever tasted and I have tried a lot of banana breads! My modifications for a healthier version, which still came out fantastic: only used 1/2 cup of sugar (granted my bananas were extremely ripe), substituted the sour cream with plain yogurt, added 1/4 cup flaxseed meal in addition to the 1.5 cup flour, and added a splash of lemon juice to the banana mixture. I followed the recipe for everything else. I baked it in 3 mini loaf pans at 350 degrees and kept an eye on them. The toothpick came out clean in about 50 minutes. Like the other reviewers mentioned, make sure your eggs and butter are room temp. I have already made this twice in the last 2 days! Thanks for a great recipe. :)

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
TRANSFERRED TO MY RECEIPE BOOK.

Sue's Delicious Banana Bread

1 cup sugar
1/2 cup butter
2 eggs
2 tbsp milk
1 tsp baking soda mixed in 1/4 cup water
2 cup flour
1/4 tsp salt
nuts (optional)
2 mashed bananas
 
Preheat oven to 350.  Make sure oven rack is second from bottom.

Put parchment paper in a bread pan and spray with non-stick spray.

Cream the sugar and butter, add the eggs.  
Add milk, baking soda and water and mix together.  Stir in the flour and salt.  Add bananas and nuts last.

Bake for 1hr 15mins.

text:
As is, I'm sure this would have been fantastic, but I did follow the tweaks of some others (cream the butter, split the sugar into brown and white sugar, mashed instead of sliced bananas). I used 3 overripe bananas (it was a little much), and also had no sour cream, so I just went without it. I must say, this bread is simply AMAZING. Probably one of the best things I have ever made.

Next time I make it, I'll use one less banana and add the sour cream, as it did seem like it would get a little dry. Definitely a keeper.

text:
On a previous occasions, I have made this recipe the way it was written and it was moist and delicious, but was trying to be a little healthier this time and use other ingredients I had on hand.  I doubled the recipe and used 1/2 all purpose flour and 1/2 whole wheat flour, I only used 1 1/4 c sugar for the double batch, instead of 2 full cups, but used about 8 extra ripe bananas which made up for the lack of the extra sugar and made it more moist, and to give it a little more of a healthy boost, I added some flax seed.  I also used half low fat sour cream and half regular fat (because I had some regular that needed to be used) I think the bread turned out just as good as the original recipe and a tiny bit healthier.

I had tried the "original" recipe when someone else made it and it was quite good. I toast it and have it with a bit of butter. 
I decided to try a few different things and it turned out well. Here's what I did: used half white sugar and half brown sugar, added a bit of cinnamom and nutmeg, and instead of regular salt, I added Chocolate Chipotle Sea Salt, since I had some (great in lots of baking!-sold at a local artisan market))I also added chocolate chips and used pecan crumbs as I didn't have walnuts.

userID:
5916263
Display Name:
anabelb

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best banana bread recipe I have tried! Since discovering it a week ago, I have made at least a dozen loaves to share with people. Everyone who tries it raves about how moist it is.  

Since I never have sour cream at home, I sour my own cream. When I preheat the oven, I throw some heavy whipping cream in a bowl with a splash of white rice vinegar. After everything is mixed I throw it in with the rest of the ingredients. I also really like this recipe with pecans instead of the walnuts. Also, as other reviewers have mentioned, I mash the bananas in a bowl before adding them to the mixing bowl. I find that it mixes more with rest of the bread.

For those who can't handle gluten, I used the same recipe with gluten free flour. I had to use a bit more flour (i just added a little more flour at a time until it was at the desired consistency). It tasted just as delicious. My gluten free friends loved this recipe and I'll definitely be making it again for them.

text:
I was pretty disappointed with this recipe actually. Seeing all the great reviews, I expected great things. I took the advice and common sense of others and mashed to banana so the bread the next day wouldn't have odd colored/too mushy chunks. Putting the sour cream in made me question what it would taste like, but I reluctantly followed the recipe. Once it was baked, it looked great, then we tried it... It wasn't terrible, but I wouldn't classify it as a bread. It has the consistency of a pound cake.
All in all, my husband didn't love it, and neither did I. We won't be making it again. It's too bad it doesn't have more average reviews (that's all it deserves).

text:
This recipe was so easy and very yummy.  The first time I made it as instructed.  Turned out great!  A lot of people complained about the slices of banana not cooking in well enough.  I used my KitchenAid mixer to mix the batter and it seemed to break the slices into small pieces that melted into the bread.  The next time I did mash the banana, and since it was right after Thanksgiving I used 1/2c of pumpkin puree in place of the other banana.  Also added a small handful (maybe 1/2c) of chocolate chips.  So good!  Thanks for this easy and versatile recipe!!

0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent and moist, loved by everyone who tries it. 

I add 3/4 cup sugar, double the vanilla and bake at 325 for 50minutes, covering with foil for the last 10 minutes. Sometimes I add in a handful of semi sweet mini chips if i want it a little sweeter.

Cream butter (always at room temp) and sugar together WELL, very well, should be a pale golden colour. Then add eggs (also room temp) and vanilla. Smash up the bananas and add the sour cream in a separate bowl, then fold into the batter. When adding the flour do it by hand (no mixer) and fold it in GENTLY, your batter should be light and airy. Makes a perfect loaf this way.

Enjoy.

text:
Loved it!  I made one batch as muffins and baked for 25 minutes.  I made a separate batch and baked as a loaf of bread.  I do not know why, but the bread tasted so much better.  The muffins did not seem to have the same strong flavor, and 2 of the muffins overflowed a little so it was a little bit of a waste. 

This is a delicious, moist bread.  I followed the ingredients  to a "T" except for slicing the bananas.  I mashed the bananas instead.  I will definitely make this again.

text:
I tried this with some minor modifications, since I am pre diabetic I like to reduce the sugar and fat.  I reduced the butter to 1/3 cup, and used splenda for 1/2 the sugar.  I also replaced half the flour with whole wheat (soft white wheat works excellent for quick bread recipes.)
I cut the bananas in quarters, and then sliced them to make smaller pieces.  Cooked as indicated and this came out perfect.  One of the best banana breads I have ever tried.

text:
I loved this recipe! It was so easy. I modified just a little: used margarine instead of butter and didn't melt it. Used 1/4 cup packed brown sugar and 3/4 cup granulated white sugar. Added cinnamon and ground cloves. Added 1/3 cup semi-sweet chocolate morsels. It was moist through the middle and had a nice crust. WILL NOT bake in only 60 minutes. I think mine was in for around 80-90 minutes using metal 9x5 loaf pan.

text:
The kids and I love this banana bread! They ask me to make it regularly and choose it for dessert and think they're getting away with something when I "let" them eat it before school. I threw out all the other banana bread recipes that I've tried before. The small changes I make...I don't melt the butter, I mush the bananas and I use chocolate chips instead of walnuts. I usually need to cook it for about 10min longer than suggested. Otherwise, it's banana perfection :)

I had a slice for breakfast this morning and I didn't have my morning snack until 11:30--it's the perfect breakfast yum!

Best banana bread I've ever made (and I make it a lot)! Easy and so moist, beautiful color. This is now my go-to recipe for banana bread. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/887470.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this banana bread, and so does my family!  I make no changes to the original posted recipe.  Some reviews state that they do not like the texture of the sliced bananas.  If you are using VERY ripe bananas, you will find that when you mix in the slices they really nearly blend in, and the texture is good.  If you use bananas that are only moderately black, to hardly black at all you will find that the slices stack in tact and do get somewhat gummy and discoloured.  Stick with really, really ripe bananas for this bread and it will not disappoint.

This is the only banana bread I will use! Over the years I've fiddled with the recipe a couple times. I use 1/4 cup butter and 1/4 cup coconut oil and mash 2- 2 1/2 cups bananas. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this and it came out AMAZING!!! :D I definitely tweaked this a little and did some stuff from other reviews i read. Instead of melting the butter, I microwave it for about 15-20 sec and then i combined half cup of white sugar & other half cup of light brown sugar. And instead of using allpurpose flour i used bread flour, since i know the bread flour would give it a different texture, i used 2 large eggs and a wee bit more sour cream (probably 1/2 tbs extra). i also added about half tsp of baking powder. and i used 3 bananas but i literally measured it after smashing them and it was a cup. put it in the oven for an hour, i turned it off in the first 50 min and left it in there for the last 10 min then took it out.

This recipe is definitely a keeper!! Thanks for sharing!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For those who need gluten free foods, I changed this recipe. I used gluten free all purpose flour, gluten free baking soda and when it came to the bananas, I mushed them, because if you can still slice the banana, it is not ripe enough to be cooked. The brown in the banana is the sugar coming to the surface, so the more brown and mushy the banana, the better the bread. This was truly a lovely Gluten free banana bread that made everybody's mouth water and ask for more. This recipe made it into my personal favs file. Awesome for sure.

text:
Bottom stuck badly, will flour pan next time. Made according to naples34102 modifications-creamed buttered with sugar tsp each of baking soda and powder. Added clove, allspice and cinnamon. Added a streusel topping of 3 TBS cold butter, heaping tablespoon of brown sugar, TBS white sugar and a TBS of flour and some cinnamon chopped until crumbly. VERY good flavor and moist! Did not rise in middle like so many recipes do. Looked just like picture. Trying next loaf now with half brown sugar, half white.

text:
I will forever be known as the banana bread girl in some circles because of this.

I had to take the recommendations from others and modify it a bit, though. I used 4 mashed, frozen bananas, and I don't think it would've been 'Banana Bread' without the addition.

I also excluded the walnuts, but that's more a personal preference.

A side note: I ended up doubling the recipe and baking in a bundt pan (don't have a 9x5). If you do this, just be prepared to cook it longer (I think it was 1 1/2 hrs...?)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Hey, I love this recipe ! ! !

I doubled the quantity because I had 5 bananas going rotten.  They were small-med size and using 5 didn't fluke the recipe.  I mashed the bananas because that's what I grew up with.

I didn't fold any walnuts in (my co-worker hates nuts and I so wanted to share this bread with my co-workers w/o any arguments) and the taste was still delicious.

I also ran out of sugar and used light brown sugar.  I just eyed and tasted the batter until I found it "right".  Still no harm done to the banana bread.

I even used 2 smaller loaf pans on 350 degrees for 30 minutes and that came out nicely, too.  I think I'll use the small pans next time because they looked "cuter."

This recipe is flexible and versatile.  I can see adding spices or more nuts, even chocolate chips to the mix would still come out moist and perfect.

P.S:  Although she's really great @ what she does F*** the Martha Stewart way of doing things.

text:
I have been using this site for over a couple of years now.  I have read many reviews but never written one before this.  I love, love this recipe.  I have made it 3 times now.  Everyone that has tasted it has also enjoyed it.  I like to read what others have written and the changes they have made.   I took advice from a couple of different readers by using 3 to 4 ripped banana mashed with a little cinnamon sugar, removed 2 tablespoon of sugar and replaced with cinnamon sugar to the butter and greased the pan with Pam buttery spray then coated spray with cinnamon sugar.  I thought it gave it a nice flavor and removed from pan easily.   This recipe is delicious.  Thank you for posting it.

text:
Moistest delicious banana bread I have ever baked :)
It was soooo good
Its only been few hours and half the loaf is gone already!

I made few modifications to make it a little bit healthier
I used 1 cup of honey powder instead of white sugar
I used 1 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour instead of all purpose flour
Used 1/2 cup of strawberry yogurt instead of sour cream

And I added a teaspoon of baking powder
2/3 cup of chopped walnuts
and 4 medium bananas mashed

I will definitely make it again!

I loved my bread moist
almost melting in mouth
But it does get your fingers sticky with banana bread goodness
I will try increasing the flour to 1 3/4 cup next time

Personally like my banana breads little bit firmed up, kept in fridge over night
Soooo good


Thank you for the wonderful recipe!

text:
I've made this twice now and it's perfect! I did make some changes though. First of all, I hate nuts so I left them out. I mashed the bananas ( like I do for banana chocolate chip muffins), I used 1/2 cup of white and 1/2 cup of brown sugar, added a little extra vanilla, and added just enough cinnamon to give it a hint of cinnamon smell. I also used 3 banana, the first time it came out perfect, but the second time I think it was too much banana ( like it came out too moist, if that's even possible). So if you like bananas like I do, I'd suggest you use 2 1/2 bananas instead of 3.

userID:
4812962
Display Name:
Zoiehcka
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading several reviews about unpleasantly dark bananas that had been sliced, I mashed mine.  

My bananas were overripe(thus my search for a Banana Bread(BB) recipe) & I had 3 so I used them all.  Some pieces were a bit bigger, but have not changed color, yet(the bread is still hot, though with a couple of slices missing!)

I baked in a glass dish for about 75 minutes.  
No problem with overflow. 

To compensate for the extra banana, I added maybe a Tablespoon more of flour.  I also used more walnuts, and maybe 2 Tablespoons LESS sugar(to make up for the extra banana and the bananas being way ripe and super sweet) but I didn't change anything else.

It smelled amazing while baking.  I thought about tenting with foil the last 30 minutes, as mentioned by another reviewer, but there was no need--it came out just a touch darker only in the very corners, with the top being golden and perfectly cracked.

It was delicious, super moist.  Would be a little better if I hadn't used 3 bananas, but stuck with 2, like the recipe states, but still delicious!

The sour cream balances the sweetness and adds moisture.
I LOVED the vanilla in this recipe, as opposed to cinnamon like most BB recipes.  

This will be my BB recipe from now on!

***Update:  I made the bread a week ago & kept in tupperware on the counter for a couple of days, as we munched away.  After that, stuck it in fridge.  Just ate one of two remaining pieces(after a few minutes in toaster oven). Still delish & pretty!

text:
I have tried two recipes of banana bread from this site and I have to say that this one is it!  This bread really is easy to make, and this coming from a guy who has never baked any cakes, bread, etc.  I followed the instructions for the most part, with the exception of using 3 bananas instead of 2, and I mashed them.  I also added 1/4 tsp of cinnamon as one person suggested.  The other recipe I had tried did not call for sour cream and I can see that adding sour cream makes a big difference in the texture of the bread - nice and moist.  Now I can't seem to stop making this. Thank you for sharing.

userID:
1690422
Display Name:
kitkat55plus
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

3
favoritesCount:
259
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I converted this to a GF (gluten free)  I am gluten intolerant.  The bread was one of the closest to "original" item that I have ever converted..and easily.  I had one banana getting too ripe and was looking for banana bread recipe I could adapt to one banana.  The sour cream was what drew me to it and it just happened to be a perfect one to half.  I used 2 mini loaf pans, baking for 40 minutes instead of 60 minutes.  Now for the gluten free flour blend.  I used 1/2 cup white rice flour, 1/4 cup potato starch and 3/4 teaspoon xanthum gum.  Full recipe measurements would be 1 cup white rice flour, 1/2 cup potato starch and 1 1/2 teaspoon xanthum gum.  I followed recipe exactly except  for the GF flour adaptation.  I used electric mixer for the whole process causing the sliced bananas to break into smaller segments which was perfect.  It was very thick dough; I had my doubts at first, but as I watched it rise and bake in oven, I knew it was a winner if the flavor was right.  My husband, who is not gluten intolerant, said it was best banana bread he had ever eaten.  Since there is just my husband and I, the 2 mini loaves worked great.  We had one to eat day of preparation and one to freeze for another time.  This is sure to become a regular taste treat in our home.  I can't rave enough about it.  Can't wait to share with my daughter whose husband has celiac disease and she and 2 of her 6 sons are gluten intolerant.  We are always on prowl for yummy GF foods.

text:
The BEST banana bread recipe ever.  I did use the variations from naples34102 which are very minor.  I only softened the butter, and then added a teaspoon each of baking soda and baking powder.  I also mixed together the bananas and sour cream before folding them into the batter.  I prefer to bake my banana bread in mini loaf pans and they took about 30 minutes to cook.  Thank you for sharing this recipe!

text:
I used half brown sugar, half white and added a little cinnamon and a few chocolate chips.  Yum!
Each time I bake something I try to make it just a bit healthier and eventually find the balance where it is healthy and still tasty.  The second time I made this with 3/4 cup sugar (half brown, half white), used greek yogurt instead of sour cream, and substituted 1/2 cup of wheat flour for 1/2 cup of the white flour.  Again, I added a little cinnamon and dark chocolate chips.  It made 18 muffins baked for about 30 minutes.  Delicious!

I just made this... and holy cow this is amazing.  I checked out other comments and did what a lot of people suggested, which was mash up the banana. So I did that rather than sliced.  The other change I made, is I used whole wheat flour rather than white flour.  It came out perfect. It is very dense, perfectly sweet bread. I think next time I might just try replacing white sugar with brown but that's it. Oh yeah, and I sprinkled even more walnuts on top of the bread right before baking... it looks nice that way and you can't get too many walnuts ^_^

text:
Great recipe! Mainly because my grandmother would make this same banana bread for us when we were little kids about 50 or so years ago. Grandmother would always have the butter at room temperature before she mixed it, and sometimes she would use chopped pecans instead of walnuts, and she would always mash the bananas first. This recipe was handed down though 3 generations of my mom's family, and  I've handed it down to my daughter and sons!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have tried a lot of recipes and I believe this one is he best.  If you make it with sliced bananas either slice it thin or half mash and half thinly slice them and you will get small nicely moist areas in your bread.  You can lessen fat content by substituting buttermilk or sour milk(1tsp vinegar + remaining 1/2 cup warmed milk) for sour cream and by using 1/4 cup applesauce + 1/4 cup butter instead of the full 1/2 cup butter.  This recipe has a great flavor and texture and with the given substitutions it doesn't taste like you are missing out on anything.

text:
Delicious! I added 4 mashed rotten bananas (I keep them frozen in my freezer for months after they turn black). To cut down on the calories I used 1/2 splenda and 1/2 sugar, used light sour cream, cut down the butter by 2 tablespoons and added 2 tablespoons of apple butter and 1 tsp. of pumpkin pie spice. Overall, I got an incredibly tasty and moist banana bread recipe which I intend to use for ages! Yum.

text:
Amazing! This was the best banana bread i have ever eaten. It did take a while to cook, but it was worth the wait. Instead of slicing the bananas, i mashed them. It made the loaf more flavorful! I added 1/8 of a teaspoon of cinnamon, and it really added to the taste. If you think you will try this recipe make sure you include the baking soda, salt, and all purpose flour. Self-rising flour just makes it heavy and flat. Trust me! Two thumbs up!

text:
Best recipe for banana bread I have ever made! I modified some things as suggest by others.  Use smashed bananas. use at least 1 cp smashed ripe bananas. cream butter at room temp. with vanilla.  add 1 tsp lemmon juice in with vanilla. use 1 tsp baking soda and 1 tsp baking powder. use 1 3/4 cp flour.  Always keep checking with a tooth pick toward the end  and bake until it comes out clean in the middle.  Perfection!!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3158466.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use this recipe all the time for banana bread or muffins. I halve the butter and sugar, use FF sour cream, whole wheat flour instead of AP, add 1 tsp baking powder, reduce baking soda to 1/2 tsp, dash of cinnamon and use 3 bananas. I do mash the bananas as my son has texture issues and the slices weren't palatable for him. If I make a large loaf I reduce the baking temp to 325 so it doesn't brown so fast, usually takes 75 minutes for large loaf, 25 minutes for muffins and 18 minutes for mini muffins.
I also omit the nuts and substitute 1/2 cup mini chocolate chips.

This is the best banana bread I have ever made. I made it early in the week because I had some overripe bananas I needed to use. I made the bread exactly as written with one exception, I mashed the bananas instead of slicing them (my personal preference), let it cool and then wrapped well and placed it in the freezer until the weekend. I made this today and it is absolutely wonderful.  The sour cream gives this loaf a nice depth of flavor and compliments the bananas very well. Recipe turned out great even after I had to substitue a few ingredients.  I didn't have sour cream so I added 1/4 of water before folding in the bananas.  I also didn't have enough butter so I added enough vegetable oil to make 1/2 cup.  I also used half brown sugar and half white then added 1/2 tsp. of cinnamon and baked in a muffin pan for about 20 mins.  Very moist!

i was a little weary about trying a banana bread with sour cream.. sounds like a really odd mix.. but aside from adding a teaspoon of baking powder i followed the recipe exatcly as written... it turned out VERY VERY moist and tasty. I have searched and tried many banana bread recipes  looking for the best and most moist bread and i feel that i have to look no further!! usually i have to let the breads rest for a day to get it nice and moist, but by the evening i baked it, it was MOIST and VERY tasty! i don't even need any butter (although im sure it would be good with some) and it doesnt taste sour creamy at all.. LOVE this recipe and defiantly adding it to the keepers log!

text:
This is a great recipe – so moist and flavorful.  It had the right amount of sweetness, and the sour cream added a nice richness to the bread.  I doubled the recipe to make 2 loaves.  To my horror, I realized I had only 1 egg left in my fridge, so I reached for a carton of liquid egg whites and used  3/4 cup to replace the 3 extra  eggs I needed.  It worked out beautifully.   I mashed and used 5 large bananas.   My bread took a bit longer, about 70 minutes.  I will definitely make this again – I may substitute splenda for white sugar next time.

text:
This was a good banana bread, but it wasn't the best I'd ever had. Slicing the banana's is a big no no. Make sure to smash them and smashed it should equal a cup. This also seemed better after a day or two. It seemed to get more moist. Overall it was good, but I would have rather it been a little sweeter and the banana's to be better distibuted throughout the bread (which would have happened had I mashed them). This is just my opinion. This might be the perfect bread for you just how it is. Don't be afraid to experiment!

I substituted 1/2 cup of brown sugar and 1/2 cup of granulated white sugar for the full cup of white sugar (as I find this gives sweet breads more color and flavor) but in this recipe, I was surprised to find that it made the bread too dark and heavy. I would stick to the recipe as is. It yields a wonderfully rich and moist banana bread that is hands down the best I've ever made!

text:
THis was a great recipe and we truly enjoyed it. I made a few changes to suit our palette which was to add 1 tsp. cinnamon and 1/2 tsp. cloves. We also mashed 3 bananas instead of the 2 since we do not like chunky bananas in our bread and prefer a stronger banana flavor. I think that if your bananas are smaller you could even do 4.  I think that next time we will add more nuts but other than that it was so yummy!!

text:
This banana bread is super yummy! I've been trying different recipes and this one definitely beats them all!  I whipped the butter and sugar on high for 2minutes and added 1tsp of baking powder. It made the recipe turn out  moist, fluffy, and light. I also added enough bananas to equal one cup and mashed them and used pecans instead of walnuts simply because i like the taste of pecans better than walnuts.  This was super delicious.. everyone should have it at least once in their lifetime!

text:
WOW!! So happy with the way this recipe came out! I made a banana bread for me and my boyfriend the other night that had me creaming the sugar and butter together and it turned out firm, nice flavor but not the greatest. I LOVED THIS PROCESS. I loved melting the butter and adding the sugar. the last step is what puts it over the top, the folding in of the sour cream, banana and pecans! (I subbed the walnuts for pecans). I mashed the bananas in the sour cream and added pecans and choc chips and folded that into the sugar egg and flour mixture.   I WOULD HIGHLY RECCOMEND THIS. Plus, it makes the house smell great.

text:
Wow I have to say this banana break isn't the healthiest (a stick of butter?!?) but it is sooooooo delicious!!!!  The only changes I made based on recommendations was to cream the butter and sugar together instead of melt the butter.  I don't know if this actually makes any kind of difference, but per standard baking rules, it seemed appropriate.  I also mashed the banana and did use my mixer to blend everything instead of folding it in to help develop the gluten a tiny bit.  My family has eaten just about the entire thing in one day, and this includes a picky 3 year old!  Yummy!!!!

text:
Believe it or not, but have made this five times since Thursday and its only Sunday!!  First time, made as directed EXCEPT no chopping of bananas, mashed is our preference.. tried leaving a few large chunks but as someone mentioned they kind of turn a weird color and don't really make it better, just weirder.  The second time I made it I ran out of sour cream and used same amount *1/2 cup* of vanilla yogurt.  My husband went crazy over the first one, but he went ape poop over the rest of them.  He's had it for breakfast, lunch and dinner AND dessert.  Not too sweet, very moist and GREAT flavor.  Haven't tried more bananas yet, don't want to mess with perfection!
Thanks!

text:
I'd give this 5 stars for ease in making but 3 for texture (as compared to my previous banana bread experiences).  I had all of the ingredients on hand and used pecans instead of walnuts and applesauce instead of butter.  I found the texture to be kind of spongy, not as soft as I would have liked; the flavor is very good though.  I made 3 wee loaves and they took 35 minutes in the oven and 10 on the baking sheet.  thanks for the recipe!

text:
Best Banana Bread!!! So good that we had to improvise! We started making Janet's Rich Banana Muffins...It was easier to "grab and go"! What a hit! Use a cookie/batter scoop, spray Jumbo baking cups and fill them about two-thirds full. *Keep banana slices chunky and mix up the nuts with 1/2 pecans and 1/2 walnuts.*
Last but not least...cut 1 tbsp butter
with 1/4 cup brown sugar, 2 tbsps flour and 1/8th tsp cinnamon. Sprinkle over muffins before baking. Only needs 25 minutes to bake at 375 degrees.

Very good recipe.  Changes I made, I added 3 VERY ripe banana's in hopes to keep the bread moist since I like to freeze it for snacks for the kids.  I also added a little bit of cloves and some cinnamon.  Also only added the chocolate chips no walnuts.  And used 1/2 cup Vanilla Yogurt instead of sour cream.  I also divided the mixture and made two small loafs.  End result...is it normal to almost eat the whole bread yourself?  WAY TO GOOD!  A little on the sweet side, probably could use less sugar if you're added just the chips and using yogurt, but still it is awesome, hoping NOT to eat the whole cake myself before the kids get home!

This recipe is quite good.  Some pointers, though -- I would mash the bananas and use 3 instead of 2.  Adding a little ground cinnamon to the batter helps with the flavor.  Also, I noticed that this bread is much, much tastier after sitting for a day on the counter or in the fridge.  Fresh out of the oven it is not nearly as good as it is later on.

This recipes happened to be my first try at banana bread, and I was pleasently surprised with how yummy the result turned out to be! I've done this recipe a number of ways now and it has turned out wonderfully with the adding of chocolate chips and the omission of nuts, if desired. Most times I've made it I have mashed two bananas and added a third banana which I chop--the banana chunks in the bread always turn out great! Five stars all around!

This is a delicious recipe! I just made a few changes because I did not have everything necessary and it still came out great. I did not have sour creme, so I substituted it with an individual size vanilla yogurt and about 1/3 cup of evaporated milk. The kids love them and can take them to school because they are nut-free.

text:
Very good.  You do not need to put margarine on this (good thing too, not exactly healthy in the first place!).  I, too, mashed the bananas.  Added bit of nutmeg with the flour - maybe 1/2 tsp? - since I noticed there were no spices.  It was mostly eaten by the time I got home from work.  A winner!
